headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Caterpillar full Year and 4Q 2015 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Mike DeWalt. Sir, the floor is yours.
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Caterpillar full Year and 4Q 2015 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Mike DeWalt. Sir, the floor is yours.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our year-end earnings call. I'm Mike DeWalt, Caterpillar's Vice President of Finance services. On the call with me this morning, we have Doug Oberhelman, our Chairman and CEO; and Brad Halverso
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our year-end earnings call. I'm Mike DeWalt, Caterpillar's Vice President of Finance services. 
On the call with me this morning, we have Doug Oberhelman, our Chairman and CEO; and Brad Halverson, our Group President and CFO. 
Now this morning, we're going to do the call similar to what we did last October. We'll be going through a short slide deck before we get to the Q&A. And if you don't have it yet, the slide deck, it's available on our website at caterpillar.com, and it's with the conference call webcast link. 
This call is copyrighted by Caterpillar Inc., and any use, recording or transmission of any portion of the call is strictly prohibited. If you'd like a copy of today's call transcript, we will be posting that in the investors section of our caterpillar.com website, and it will be in the section labeled Results Webcast. 
This morning, we'll be discussing forward-looking information that certainly involves risks and uncertainties and assumptions that could cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking information. A discussion of some of those factors individually or in the aggregate that could make actual results to differ materially from our projections, well, that can be found in our cautionary statements under Item 1A, which is risk factors, and our 10-K filed last February, and it's in the forward-looking statements language in today's financial release and near the front of this morning's slide deck. 
In addition, a reconciliation of non-GAAP measures can also be found in today's financial release. And again, that's been posted on our website at caterpillar.com. 
Okay, with that, let's get started. If I could ask you to pull out the slide deck and flip to Page 4 -- or I'm sorry, Page 3, and that's the agenda of our slide deck. I'll start this morning with a quick review of the fourth quarter and the full year of '15 and the outlook for 2016, and then I'll hand off to Doug, and he'll cover a few of the key points that we were trying to make in this morning's financial release. 
So with that, let's flip to what would be Page 4 of the bottom of the slide deck. And this is the fourth quarter 2015 results versus fourth quarter 2004 ( sic ) [ 2014 ] And you can see on here that sales and revenues are down $3.2 billion from $14.2 billion to $11 billion. That's a 23% drop. And I'll kind of talk about that 2 ways. First, about $2.7 billion of that was lower volume, selling fewer things, and most of that was lower end-user demand. About $400 million of it was related to reductions in dealer inventory. Price realization was negative in the quarter, about $124 million, and we did have a stronger dollar versus the fourth quarter of '14, which caused us our sales outside the U.S. to translate into fewer dollars, and in this case, quarter-over-quarter, a negative of about $400 million. So that's the $3.2 billion. If you look at that by segment, the biggest decline was Energy & Transportation. It was off $1.8 billion. About $8.8 billion of that was CI, construction, and about half of that, a little more than half of that, was where the dealer inventory impact was most concentrated, and then about $0.5 billion was Resource Industries. And again, that's mostly mining. So the decline was across the board, but a bit more concentration -- concentrated quarter-over-quarter in Energy & Transportation. And I think given what's happened to oil prices over the course of the past year, that's probably not a big surprise. 
Now the profit impact of those changes or that decline in sales volume was about $940 million negative. The next largest item quarter-over-quarter is restructuring cost, and they were negative $585 million. They went from $97 million in the fourth quarter a year ago to $682 million this year. And a lot of that increase is a result of the fairly significant actions that we announced last September and are in the middle of implementing right now. Costs, though, were favorable, about $461 million, and that's pretty much all in, excluding restructuring versus a year ago. So that's good news. 
Now taxes, I know it's probably a little hard to follow what's happening with taxes. It was a very low kind of all-in tax impact in both quarters. The rate this year is a little lower than last year, and we had $85 million of favorable tax items in the fourth quarter of '14 and $77 million in the fourth quarter of '15. So a little bit hard to follow, but not a massive impact quarter-over-quarter. 
If we look at the profit numbers on the table up above, all-in profit in the fourth quarter a year ago was $1.23. We actually had a loss of $0.15 in the fourth quarter of '15, and a lot of that was because of the significant restructuring costs. So the all-in change was a decline of $1.38 a share. Excluding the restructuring costs in '14, the fourth quarter was $1.35. The fourth quarter of '15 was $0.74, and we were down $0.61. We continue to report our results both with and without restructuring costs. We think it's important to help you kind of understand what's going on in the business. So that's the fourth quarter. 
Let's flip to Page 5. That's the full year. It was obviously a tough year for us in 2015. Sales were off $8.2 billion. Vast majority of that was lower sales volume, but the stronger dollar impacted the full year in kind of the same way it did the quarter. In terms of segments, Energy & Transportation was the largest decline at $3.8 billion. That was oil, rail, electric power. So fairly widespread within E&T. Construction Industries was down $2.8 billion and Resource Industries $1.4 billion. So from a profit standpoint, all in, we were $5.88 in 2014, all in, including restructuring, we dropped to $3.50 in 2015, and that's a decline of $2.38 a share. More than all of that is the decline in volume. If you take out restructuring costs, we were $6.38 in '14 and $4.64 in '15, down $1.74. And I think the story for '15 is big sales headwind, $8.2 billion, but we worked really hard on lowering costs. We took significant restructuring actions, and new restructuring actions began in the third quarter. Our costs were about $520 million favorable, and that's net of about $350 million of unfavorable cost absorption. So let me explain that a little bit. 
In 2014, sales were pretty flat with 2013, not a big change. So inventory didn't change much. It was down $400 million in '14. In '15 -- so inventory absorption wasn't a big deal in '14. In '15, inventory declined $2.5 billion. So that's $2.1 billion more than it did in 2015, and there's a pretty significant cost impact to that sizable decline in inventory. Order of magnitude, 350. And so without that, costs would have been even more favorable. 
Share count was positive to profit year-over-year, about $0.16 a share, and that's -- a lot of that is the full year impact of the significant repurchases we did in '14 and a partial year impact of the repurchases that we did in '15. Overall, bottom line, all in on tax, not much change year-over-year. So that's the full year. And if you take out the restructuring costs, I'll just mention that our decremental operating profit margins were about 20%, and we would consider that to be pretty good performance. It's better than our 25% to 30% target. 
So let's flip to the next page, Page 6. Now Page 6 is a little discussion on how we did versus our outlook. And in this case, where -- since so much has transpired over the year, we're kind of taking a long look back, how did we do versus what we told you we thought we would do a year ago right now in our year-end call for '14 and then how did we come out versus the outlook that we had in place at the end of October, the last conference call that we had, the third quarter financial release. 
And so if you look down the numbers, in January a year ago, we were expecting sales and revenues this year to be $50 billion, profit per share to be $4.60, restructuring costs to be only another $150 million, and then profit per share, excluding those restructuring costs, to be around $4.75.
Now what we actually had was sales and revenues that were $47 billion, and that's in the third column, which were $3 billion below where we thought they would be when we started the year. And I think everything that's happened with oil prices, commodities, in general, increased weakness in China, most of the sales decline that we actually had in '15, we'd anticipated in that outlook. We were down from that about $3 billion. Profit per share is lower by $1.10, and quite a bit of that is restructuring costs were a lot higher. And again, that's because we announced pretty substantial new actions in September. So excluding restructuring costs, we were at $4.64, and that's $0.11 a share shy of where our outlook was when we started the year. And I think our view would be, on a $3 billion sales decline, even given all the puts and takes, that's pretty good performance. 
Now versus the last outlook that we provided in late October of 2015, we said our outlook was going to be about $48 billion, and we kind of clarified that a little further as somewhere in the range of $47 billion and $48 billion. We were looking at profit per share of $3.70, and that included $800 million of restructuring costs. And then excluding restructuring, we were looking at $460 million. Well, what we actually did was a little worse on sales. It's been a continuing challenging environment. Profit per share was lower, and that's largely because we had more restructuring costs than we expected at the time. Excluding restructuring, we ended up the year at 4 64 . Actually, a little ahead of our outlook. Now I'd seen a few of this morning's analyst reports. And for sure, we did not have the tax extenders in our previous outlook. So that was an unanticipated benefit for us. And in several analyst reports, I think you picked that up. The flip side of that is we also have a fairly sizable charge for a legal matter in our fourth quarter. We didn't expect that either, and it really wasn't related to operations, if you will, in the quarter. And those 2 items about offset each other. So I would say, all in, despite lower sales, we did a little bit better than our outlook, and we're pretty pleased with that. 
So let's talk about 2016. A lot going on in 2016. So let's flip to Page 7. First, we'll do sales and revenue. It looks to us like another tough year. We don't really forecast -- we're not forecasting any real improvement in the overall world economy. We're not banking on commodities getting better. And as a result of that, we're looking at $40 billion to $44 billion in sales and revenues. A midpoint there is about $42 billion. Now that is about $3.5 billion below where we were thinking last October when we gave a preliminary outlook. And I think that's probably not too surprising to most of you with the continued slide in oil prices to down around $30 a share, and I would say continuing concern and worry around emerging markets, particularly China. 
So as we look at next year and what we think will happen with sales or what we're expecting, another down year for Energy & Transportation, down 10% to 15%. Now quite a bit of that decline is around timing. So we knew oil prices were coming down last year. We expected that to weaken pretty substantially in 2014, and it did. But most of that reduction was in the second half of the year. We started 2014 with a pretty sizable backlog, and we sold out the backlog for the first half of the year in Energy & Transportation, particularly in the reciprocating engines for the -- for oil customers. So if you look at Energy & Transportation, that their first half of '14, they -- or I'm sorry, the first half of '15, they were only down 6% versus the prior year. Second half of the year was down 27%. That is kind of how we thought it would play in. It's what we signaled at the beginning of the year, stronger first half, weaker second half. And now we see kind of that level of business continuing on with the recent oil and gas business out on into 2015. 
Construction Industries, we're looking at being down 5% to 10%. In Resource Industries, down another 15% to 20%. Now on Resource Industries, the bad news is that it looks like it's down another 15% to 20%. That's really a tough business in mining. Very few orders. Many of our customers are in sort of challenged financial conditions. But what I would say is sales of new equipment in that number are quite low. You never want to say never about upside and downside risk, but there's so little new equipment in there. I think it's fair to say the downward-side risk is somewhat limited. 
In terms of profit per share, we put in a table here, and this is a table that was in our financial release, so a lot of moving parts. So I thought it would help to walk through it piece by piece. So if you look at our outlook for 2016, all in, profit per share, we're looking at $3.50, and that includes restructuring costs and that includes pension changes that we are making. 
We're making a change in accounting principle. It relates to our defined benefit plans primarily. It's positive to our results about $0.50 a share. And the way you want to think about this is we're moving from an accounting method that smooths actuarial gains and losses from prior years into current year results. And we're moving from that to a method that's kind of more mark-to-market and will move closer -- will be a closer representation of what our current year costs really are. And that's favorable, about $425 million in and of itself, and that's about $0.50 a share. We also have another $400 million or so of restructuring costs in our outlook, and that's about $0.50. So all in, excluding restructuring costs, we're at $4 a share. So that's the outlook for 2016 on sales and profit. In terms of profit, the negatives are lower sales as we go into 2016 from 47 down to the midpoint would be $42 billion. So at the midpoint, that's a $5 billion profit drop, offset by considerable cost reduction. A lot of that as a result of the restructuring actions that we started to put in place by September. 
So with that, I'll turn the floor over to Doug Oberhelman.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good morning, everyone. And I do want to make a few key points as I look back on '15 and forward into '16. Mike said it. It was a very tough year, but when you think about everything that happened, the challenges, the chaos at sometime during the ye
componenttext:
Okay, good morning, everyone. And I do want to make a few key points as I look back on '15 and forward into '16. Mike said it. It was a very tough year, but when you think about everything that happened, the challenges, the chaos at sometime during the year with events around the world, a year ago today, we were expecting $50 billion in sales. We ended up at $47 billion. That $3 billion is quite a drop, but we really only reduced our profit per share outside of restructuring by $0.11. And as Mike said, there's a lot involved in that, up and down. But basically, I'm pretty pleased with cost management, the restructuring actions we took in the fourth quarter. Actually, they were more aggressive than we had planned and announced, and we took about $100 million more because of it, but that will serve us well for 2016. So our team really did a good job, and I -- it's tough to say, but I -- we're getting used to cycles here. 2009 volume at $32 billion, we doubled the company in 3 years to 2012. We're down about 30% from that now, and that will serve this team very well in the years and decades ahead as we have to go through these kind of cycles and short dates. Secondly, operationally, was one of our -- 2015 was on of our better years. One thing, and I've talked about this before, one of the proxies I used for plant management is their safety record. And when I go to plants, I look at -- for that matter, when I go to customers' job sites, it's the same thing. But it -- there's a safe environment. They tell me about it. Their numbers are good. Chances are, we're going to see high quality. We're going to see engaged employees. We're going to see a profitable plan. And safety for us hit a record level of for recordable injury frequency in 2015 at 0.6, which is really world-class, we think, for heavy manufacturing. Our market position, fifth year in a row of improvement around the world in virtually across all markets, for that matter, and most all products. And I think that goes back to saying something about the quality of our product, the quality of our design, our Tier 4 implementation as well as our dealer distribution organization, which right now is very strong. And finally, Mike mentioned it, but I would point it out again, our decremental operating profit of 20%, if you really look at that without restructuring, I think it's really 17%. And while that granted happened in the fourth quarter, but that's what we learned to do. So very happy with that, and again sets us up for '16 so well. 
Our balance sheet is strong. Put some of the data in the release this morning. We saw a lot of free cash flow, about $5.2 billion in 2015. Another great year. Certainly, we'll see another positive cash flow year this year, more than enough to cover our dividend and our CapEx. I would say that we are scrubbing CapEx very hard and taking a -- really close look at every line item. We'll get that number down below '15, and we're still working through it. And finally, our focus on use of cash, as you know, has been fairly well stated over the years. But at the moment, it's our balance sheet, our credit rating and protecting our dividend. And with the cash we have on the balance sheet, with the leverage we have today, which is the best it's ever been at this stage of the cycle, I'm going back to many, many of our downturns, we feel pretty good about that. But that's really a high priority for us today is to protect that dividend and that balance sheet. 
We did a little conference call in November around Cat Financial. We really like that business. It's strategic to us. We would not have the market position we have without Cat Financial and the loyalty with our customers. Actually, in 2015, they hit a very high market share number for what they financed. The quality of that asset portfolio is very good. Past dues actually improved a little bit from 2014. And just to emphasize that we really, at Cat Financial, only use that captive finance company to finance Caterpillar products, yellow iron -- or yellow iron inside other products -- or yellow irons is a big piece of it. We have not varied from that strategy. We won't vary from that strategy. It is so key and crucial for us to delivering our market performance around the world, and it's a really well-managed company, and it's really helping us through the cycles as well. 
Looking at 2016, tough market. I would expect bumps in the road all through the year. We've taken that outlook down to $42 billion, another drop of $5 billion, lower 10% reduction. About 30% off our peak in '12. And I expect to see, frankly commodities of all stripes and all kinds, and oil for that matter, not to move too much. It can move up or down. We'll see what happens. But we're really going into this with eyes wide open, realistic view that we're going to end up the year with what we went into it with it -- where we are in commodity markets and other economies as well. Brazil, Russia, some of the areas where have been really challenged. We're baking into this outlook, continued tough times in a lot of those markets as well. So I really am hoping that this is a very realistic look. We've got some restructuring -- more restructuring coming to us that will help. We think we're about right-sized for right now. Of course, we've got some of the restructuring that we'll be announcing as early as tomorrow, with another one -- another round that will fulfill some of the things that we talked about in September. 
I also want to talk about inventory a little bit. We think we're pretty close and really not that excessive with inventory around the world, but we probably will see a slight somewhere reduction in dealer inventory. We've actually been producing at factory rates less than retail sales for a while, and as a result, seen dealer inventory drop $1 billion in their own drop, $2.5 billion. So we've really seen a drop here in the last year, which again sets us up nicely into 2016. 
Then a little bit more restructuring. I think we are committed to that pull-through number of 25% to 30%, up or down. As I said, we're 17% to 20% in 2015. We announced at September our goal was 4,000 to 5,000 positions eliminated by the end of the year. In fact, we were slightly over 5,000 on the 1st of January. And with a few more to go. Yet early in '16, which should fulfill that program and our cost-reduction goals. 
Finally, and this is the one that's good news. I feel really good about them. I'm going to talk about it for a minute. That's our efforts around digital technology, innovation and R&D. We increased R&D slightly in 2015. We're going to hold it at about that level as long as we can in 2016. And I would just point out that we also did something similar to this in '09 and '10 at the depths of the recession. We cut R&D, but we didn't cut it to the bone. That was the one thing that we held on to as long as we could. And those efforts in research and development that we made at that time of new products have hit the marketplace in our Tier 4 interim and final products being introduced. The last of them this year, and we've seen a substantial increase in the quality of the products, the design of products and acceptance in the marketplace, not to mention the fuel economies across the board. Today, we're in the same boat, post Tier 4 with lots of powertrain development, all kinds of alternative proportion methods coming through, which will be coming out of products in '17, '18 and '19. We want to continue that because we've seen the benefits of that, and market share will see the benefits of that in the future. We're going to do all we can to hold that. So while it's a high number, and subject to cut if we have to, and we will, we're doing all we can to preserve that. And then around the digital technology space. You've seen an awful lot of utterances from us last year, information of a joint venture with a key partner, closer ties with our existing and traditional partners as well. The digital transformation is occurring, a reality, and we are going to lead this in our industry. While it's challenging and our cycle would probably -- if we had a better cycle, we probably spend more. We're doing all we can to extend our leadership in this area. What we're aiming at is quite a bit different than others. I would say we're aiming at the Internet of Caterpillar things, so that when we think about what we're doing with digital technology, what we're doing with site preparation and technology, machine guidance technology, machine health technology, it's all about our installed base of 3,000 machines -- 3 million machines and engines. Rail, construction, mining, the things we do. We have no interest in going beyond that because we want to take care of our customers as we have been doing for 90 years. We have the domain knowledge of what our customers use our machines to do. We have knowledge of our machines. Our idea is to make a ready platform, lots of sensors, across our machines and other brands, to make sure that our customer gets the most out of that construction equipment in his or her fleet. I suspect that in the next year, 2 or 5, this will be a tremendous day. We'll be talking a lot more to you at our investor meetings and so on as we get there. Just this month, we're commercializing our locomotive Internet technology. That led all of our segments, and it's now ready to go. We're in the middle stages of taking that. The construction equipment will have some of that ready midyear and a lot of it by the end of the year. But the idea here is really a lot of value creation for customers, reducing downtime and lowering owning and operating cost by predicting failures, by allowing them to take less passes across a parking lot, for example, better fuel economies and efficiencies as a result, all through this overwhelming amount of data that we can now receive, process and feed back to our customers, our dealers and even our factories in a way that we've never been able to do it before level. I have to say on this, there's been a lot been written about it. I'm really happy where we are, and our speed to market on this is un-Caterpillar-like in terms of iron development. I'm quite happy about, and that's why we've gone to outside partners. 
So Mike, I'll turn it back over to you with those comments.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thanks, Doug. Paul, we're ready to open the floor for Q&A.
componenttext: All right. Thanks, Doug. Paul, we're ready to open the floor for Q&A.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question is coming from Jerry Revich.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question is coming from Jerry Revich.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Goldman Sachs. I'm wondering if you could talk about your expectations for Solar, just flesh that out for us, if you could, Mike, this year and comment on cadence over the course of the year. Within the past month, we've seen pipeline, MLPs, cut CapE
componenttext: It's Goldman Sachs. I'm wondering if you could talk about your expectations for Solar, just flesh that out for us, if you could, Mike, this year and comment on cadence over the course of the year. Within the past month, we've seen pipeline, MLPs, cut CapEx, and wondered if you could just calibrate what you're seeing in the order book.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question, Jerry. Happy to do that. So as usual, Solar, as is almost usual, Solar had a great fourth quarter of 2015. We expected that. And in fact, they did. Backlog for Solar was despite that big shipping quarter in the fourth quarter, it was a
componenttext: Yes, good question, Jerry. Happy to do that. So as usual, Solar, as is almost usual, Solar had a great fourth quarter of 2015. We expected that. And in fact, they did. Backlog for Solar was despite that big shipping quarter in the fourth quarter, it was about the same at year-end as it was at the end of the third quarter. So no deterioration in their backlog. In fact, if you look at Solar's total backlog, it's about the same as it was at the end of '14. What's happened to their business is the oil piece of it has declined quite a bit. The natural gas piece of it is holding up quite nicely. We kind of signaled that we would have some reduction in Solar in the third -- in the third quarter, we did the preliminary outlook. We said they would likely decline but less than 10%. Nothing's really changed there.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then separately, Doug, the last point that you made, the Caterpillar Internet of things. Can you talk about your expectations in 5 years? Are we looking at a significant revenue and profit pool for your business? What kind of business model should we
componenttext: And then separately, Doug, the last point that you made, the Caterpillar Internet of things. Can you talk about your expectations in 5 years? Are we looking at a significant revenue and profit pool for your business? What kind of business model should we be thinking about for you folks to monetize all of the valuable fleet that you have in the field and the opportunity to monetize that data? How should we think about the business model?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it will be -- it's not going to be a software charge-out system at all. We're going to measure it. And the benefit to us will be in aftermarket parts, aftermarket service in connection to the customer through the products that we sell and service. An
componenttext: Yes, it will be -- it's not going to be a software charge-out system at all. We're going to measure it. And the benefit to us will be in aftermarket parts, aftermarket service in connection to the customer through the products that we sell and service. And that's really where we're headed as opposed to a software-for-fee basis. Pretty simple. And just as an adjunct to what we're already doing in so many of our areas today aiming directly at our customers.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is coming from Robert Wertheimer.
componenttext: And your next question is coming from Robert Wertheimer.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Barclays. I guess a dual question on price and costs. You've had a little bit of lower pricing, although I think under your leadership, Doug, you guys have been very, very competitive and gained a lot of share and not major [indiscernible] the price.
componenttext: It's Barclays. I guess a dual question on price and costs. You've had a little bit of lower pricing, although I think under your leadership, Doug, you guys have been very, very competitive and gained a lot of share and not major [indiscernible] the price. So I get that. But you still have a little bit of contraction in price. So is there anything major going on with either currency? Or is it inventory flush? Or what's doing that? And are you able to continue to get cost back from your suppliers? Are you sort of ahead of the curve there? Or is that -- does that continue to flow through into '17, the materials moves we've already seen?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, this is Mike. I'll start this out. I'm going to start a little bit with material cost. We've done actually very well over the last 3, 4 years on material cost. I think we've, in combination, taken out over $1 billion. So over that time -- I mean, las
componenttext: Rob, this is Mike. I'll start this out. I'm going to start a little bit with material cost. We've done actually very well over the last 3, 4 years on material cost. I think we've, in combination, taken out over $1 billion. So over that time -- I mean, last year, '15, was a good chunk of that. So it's been a combination of actually lower commodity prices that helped some, but all the work we've done on Lean, resourcing, engineer value chains, our investments in R&D, our partnerships with suppliers have helped generate a pretty good chunk of that cost reduction as well. So if you relate that to our price realization, that was a net benefit for us in 2015. I mean we have continued good material cost reduction, and our pricing overall was pretty neutral. It was favorable in the first half of the year, unfavorable in the second half. As we look ahead to 2016, that will probably shift down a little bit. I think given where commodity prices are right now, we're not expecting as much benefit because we don't see another big leg down. So the material cost reduction that we have in has a bit more of a concentration on the things that we do to get it. And by the same token, price realization is tougher. And I think, in large part -- or a chunk of what's going on, particularly in construction, is we've had a stronger dollar over the course of the past year. There are translation effects of that that happened immediately. We are selling in euros in Europe, and that changes. But the competitive effects on -- in the U.S. and in countries where, say, we didn't come out to our -- competing against each other, say, whether it be Latin America or Europe, I think the impact of the stronger dollar was starting to bite a little bit. Another thing that's hurt us on price a bit, and particularly the fourth quarter, and this might be a little bit hard to follow, but actually, where we're selling product matters a bit. We have different price levels in different parts of the world. And I would tell you, if you look at construction in the fourth quarter, there was a large decline in Latin America, like 49%, I think, in CI. We tend to have better price realization there than we do in some other parts of the world, and sort of that hurt the overall kind of average price in the quarter as well. So I guess, bottom line, stronger dollar, I think, very competitive environment with volumes lower, a little bit of negative geography for us. The flip side of that is still continued good work on material costs.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A little philosophy here. You alluded to what we tried to do over the last few years, and you're exactly right. That's raised our market share. We've had -- we've done well with that. That won't change. This business is run on field population. And as lon
componenttext: A little philosophy here. You alluded to what we tried to do over the last few years, and you're exactly right. That's raised our market share. We've had -- we've done well with that. That won't change. This business is run on field population. And as long as that field population is building, it allows our dealers to really survive in tough times like these and thrive in good times. And that's going to continue. But we have baked a little bit more in, as Mike said, for price. We got the dollar situation. We've got excess capacity with competitors all over the place, and we think we can juggle that in a way where we can continue to move our market position up while kind of guarding the margin as well. But it's a balance. It's the same balance we've been working on the last 5 or 6 years.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is coming from Joel Tiss.
componenttext: And your next question is coming from Joel Tiss.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bank of Montréal. I just wonder if you can help us a little bit with some first half, second half color, especially in E&T. You're going to have tough comps obviously in the first half of the year. Can you give us any idea, like revenue decline first hal
componenttext: Bank of Montréal. I just wonder if you can help us a little bit with some first half, second half color, especially in E&T. You're going to have tough comps obviously in the first half of the year. Can you give us any idea, like revenue decline first half versus second half or anything to help us figure that out?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Joel. I mentioned -- I know I said a lot earlier. But if we look back at '15, we had a lot more decline in the second half of the year than in the first half of the year. And that's because the first half of last year was helped by the size of the ba
componenttext: Yes, Joel. I mentioned -- I know I said a lot earlier. But if we look back at '15, we had a lot more decline in the second half of the year than in the first half of the year. And that's because the first half of last year was helped by the size of the backlog, particularly around drilling and well servicing. That's pretty well gone now. So I think it's safe to say that, year-over-year, in that decline that we're expecting for Energy & Transportation, the 10 to 15, it will probably be more than in the first half and less than that in the second half. We don't really do the quarterly breakdown. But your sentiment, what you're thinking is absolutely correct. Year-over-year, a lot tougher in the first half than the second half. I know that wasn't detailed, but...

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But basically, I get between the lines, you're saying that that business is expected to be pretty much flat for the year, so we can just figure out what that means.
componenttext: Okay. But basically, I get between the lines, you're saying that that business is expected to be pretty much flat for the year, so we can just figure out what that means.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no. Down 10 to 15, but probably down more than that in the first half and probably less than half in the second half.
componenttext: No, no, no. Down 10 to 15, but probably down more than that in the first half and probably less than half in the second half.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Yes, yes. Okay. And any signs of any aftermarket business stabilizing? That's usually the early warning signs that we're in deep enough into a downturn that things are starting to stabilize.
componenttext: Right. Yes, yes. Okay. And any signs of any aftermarket business stabilizing? That's usually the early warning signs that we're in deep enough into a downturn that things are starting to stabilize.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, from -- on a percentage and even dollar basis, the change -- and aftermarket has gone down. No doubt about that, over the last couple years. But the decline is much less than what's happened in new equipment. And the fourth quarter was down aga
componenttext: Yes. Well, from -- on a percentage and even dollar basis, the change -- and aftermarket has gone down. No doubt about that, over the last couple years. But the decline is much less than what's happened in new equipment. And the fourth quarter was down again. So right now, I would say there's no signs that that's really kicking up. But the longer customers work existing machines and don't replace, and as long as the output tends to hold up at some point here, that will need to happen. So far, it hasn't.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Ross Gilardi.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Ross Gilardi.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bank of America. So Mike, I believe you guys normally have your annual impairment sets in the fourth quarter. It doesn't look like you booked any impairments. And even though you had [indiscernible] competitor just write off 50% of its book value. So I'm
componenttext: Bank of America. So Mike, I believe you guys normally have your annual impairment sets in the fourth quarter. It doesn't look like you booked any impairments. And even though you had [indiscernible] competitor just write off 50% of its book value. So I'm just wondering if you could talk about that. I mean you're speaking very candidly about all the pressures in the mining business that you've now been feeling for 4 years in a row. So can you talk about the rationale for not writing down a big portion of goodwill on the back of this latest test?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can do that. So first, the current mining business is weak. There is no doubt about that. Second, what I would tell you is we just, in the fourth quarter, to your point, we completed an impairment test with what we believe is a pretty realistic for
componenttext: Yes, I can do that. So first, the current mining business is weak. There is no doubt about that. Second, what I would tell you is we just, in the fourth quarter, to your point, we completed an impairment test with what we believe is a pretty realistic forecast going forward. And we had no impairment. We will -- if there's an event that causes us or triggers us to do it again before the next fourth quarter, we'll do that. I mean we did the math. There's no impairment. I think one thing you need to remember about this business is it's highly cyclical. Where the business is at today, at least from our piece of it, the sales of equipment to that industry, we're well below replacement level. It has to return, and to at least a replacement level, over time. If you do an impairment test, and that's a long-term view of what's going to happen, it's not based on what's going to happen next year. And we've done that consistent with the way we have. We didn't have an impairment. I don't know what else to say about that. I'm not on the inside in our competitors' accounting department, so it's hard for me to comment on what they did.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Doug, just had kind of a bigger-picture question. I mean the last couple of days, we have Zoom Line bidding for Terex publicly. And while they might not be a huge direct competitor of Caterpillar's, does the prospect of a big Chinese OEM buying a
componenttext: And then Doug, just had kind of a bigger-picture question. I mean the last couple of days, we have Zoom Line bidding for Terex publicly. And while they might not be a huge direct competitor of Caterpillar's, does the prospect of a big Chinese OEM buying a listed U.S. company potentially set a precedent that concerns Caterpillar?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We saw Sonny I don't know, 3 or 4 years ago and become really a dominant player, and maybe the dominant player in concrete pumping. Crane business is still pretty broad. I would guess we're going to see more Chinese investment in the United States in all
componenttext: We saw Sonny I don't know, 3 or 4 years ago and become really a dominant player, and maybe the dominant player in concrete pumping. Crane business is still pretty broad. I would guess we're going to see more Chinese investment in the United States in all kinds of things. We'll see how this one sorts out if it actually closes up, but it wouldn't surprise me to see some of that. Yes, I expect that's probably a strategy. If I were sitting over there in China, I'd be looking at some of this also. I would expect to see some of that. I don't think it's going to be an overwhelming wave of things. But certainly, they're growing. And we've always said we'll see 1, 2 or 3 emerging Chinese competitors of some kind and maybe that's a move like that around our industry, not certainly not in it. we don't really play too much against that anymore. Although Terex is a good supplier through the Jini brand to our dealers.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from David Raso.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from David Raso.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Evercore ISI. I just wonder if you could help us a little bit with the cadence of the earnings for '16, just given the moving parts around the restructuring savings. Can you give us some pace on that? And even the accounting changes, is it simply a linear
componenttext: Evercore ISI. I just wonder if you could help us a little bit with the cadence of the earnings for '16, just given the moving parts around the restructuring savings. Can you give us some pace on that? And even the accounting changes, is it simply a linear day 1 and just run in out per quarter? Just for some sense of a cadence exiting '16.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David. Actually, excellent question. On the pension, those -- that just plays into what the annual cost is, and that will be spread evenly, essentially, over the course of the year. In terms of the restructuring, most of the -- at least the short-ter
componenttext: Yes, David. Actually, excellent question. On the pension, those -- that just plays into what the annual cost is, and that will be spread evenly, essentially, over the course of the year. In terms of the restructuring, most of the -- at least the short-term benefit that we were expecting for 2016, it's a result of heads out. And that is, as Doug said, on target -- a little ahead of on target. So the vast majority of that will -- the middle we gave you is a full year number. So the vast majority of that is already happened as of the first of the year. So that should be pretty good to divide by 4. Not -- -- probably not quite that. There's a bit more still to happen, but probably not massively of dividing by 4 because a lot of the actions are effective at the end of the year this year.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's what I was trying to think about, with some of the savings upfront and the pension accounting help upfront, when you look at the $4 number, ex restructuring, any help at all on how you think about the cadence and through the year?
componenttext: That's what I was trying to think about, with some of the savings upfront and the pension accounting help upfront, when you look at the $4 number, ex restructuring, any help at all on how you think about the cadence and through the year?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you just look at last couple of quarters, we've been right around $11 billion. Now the first and second quarter of '15, we're higher. But again, that was before some of the declines that we were expecting, like oil and gas. So I think as we've kin
componenttext: Yes, if you just look at last couple of quarters, we've been right around $11 billion. Now the first and second quarter of '15, we're higher. But again, that was before some of the declines that we were expecting, like oil and gas. So I think as we've kind of gone down for oil and gas that's out of the backlog. I think if you look at the kind of sales cadence for next year, it probably won't be massively off what a normal distribution is for us. So probably a little bit lower in the first quarter, a little bit higher in the fourth and second quarters and a little bit lower in the third quarter. From a profit standpoint, first quarter will have a little bit below average sales. Likely, it's middle of winter, not really the selling season, so probably a little bit weaker than average. So that will impact profits, the downside a little bit. Flip side of that is the first quarter is usually a pretty good cost quarter. So that usually helps the first quarter a little bit. So we're not actually providing guidance. But for the quarter -- but all in all, as you do your modeling, I would think about probably first quarter down a little bit from the average profit, probably not massively far off it.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And last question, Doug. You spoke to commodity prices. You're not assuming much recovery to the end markets, not much recovery. But how are you managing for '17? Saying it another way, if commodities are, at the end of this year, where they are tod
componenttext: Okay. And last question, Doug. You spoke to commodity prices. You're not assuming much recovery to the end markets, not much recovery. But how are you managing for '17? Saying it another way, if commodities are, at the end of this year, where they are today, thinking through the inventory reduction you're targeting, $1 billion at dealers, just how should we think about 2017 if commodities are at the end of the year where they are today? I mean you take us through your thoughts on replacement demand, inventory, [indiscernible] look at the dealer inventory. I mean we went up $4.5 billion, $5 billion coming out of the Great Recession. In the last 3 years, we've taken $5 billion out. So we're -- I can't say the inventory is down a lot over the last 6 years. It kind of went up or back down. Is taking $1 billion out enough? I'm just trying to set the stage a little how you're managing for '17.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, right now, it's all hands on deck for '16. And hopefully, we can get that done. I would say around inventory and inventory turnover, as we have been implementing Lean and all of our initiatives around our Cat Production System, I feel -- you know wh
componenttext: Well, right now, it's all hands on deck for '16. And hopefully, we can get that done. I would say around inventory and inventory turnover, as we have been implementing Lean and all of our initiatives around our Cat Production System, I feel -- you know what I feel -- the fact that we've taken 30% off the top line and inventory down about the same amount or so just to stay even in that falling cycle is just pretty darn good. Once we get stable at a bottom to slightly rising turn, whatever that is, in a stable production schedule, I suspect our inventory turnover is going to be very, very acceptable and ought to help us. That's about as far as I would go with that, David. Because I don't know if oil or commodities where they'll be a year from now. And I really don't want to think about that, other than inventory turnover and efficiency in the plants and variable margins, that's what's going to get us to that.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, this is Brad. Maybe one comment around how we're approaching relative 2 priorities. So we didn't talk a lot about our actions up until September, but we have taken significant restructuring action to that point. But again, in June really of 2015, w
componenttext: David, this is Brad. Maybe one comment around how we're approaching relative 2 priorities. So we didn't talk a lot about our actions up until September, but we have taken significant restructuring action to that point. But again, in June really of 2015, we restarted a process internally that led to our September restructuring effort. By and large, the cost reduction we're talking about, the period cost had protected R&D and our digital spend and other priorities. So we've seen a significant reduction in a lot of the support areas in terms of consolidation and efficiencies. I bring this up because sometimes we get the question "What are you going to if sales continue to drop?" But I can tell we're continuing to work that plan. We understand and have committed to our decremental pull-throughs. And so sales do drop, we may have to cut those [indiscernible] but we have other restructuring efforts that we're continuing to look and will be prepared and take action on those.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Jamie Cook.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Jamie Cook.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Credit Suisse. I guess 2 questions. One, Doug, you addressed a lot of -- I guess, your confidence level with the balance sheet and protecting the dividend. But can you give any color on how you think about sort of cash flow in 2016 if you look at over the
componenttext: Credit Suisse. I guess 2 questions. One, Doug, you addressed a lot of -- I guess, your confidence level with the balance sheet and protecting the dividend. But can you give any color on how you think about sort of cash flow in 2016 if you look at over the past years, working capital has been a big source. I guess, the concern is that sort of running out. And if earnings are down in '17 and the balance sheet is sort of at risk. So your thoughts on that. And then Mike, I guess if you -- you gave us a lot of help on the top line. I'm just trying to think about any color you're giving on margins by segment as I see resources still not profitable. And in particular, E&T had a thing about margins as we exit the year because I think that's a concern as we approach '17 with [indiscernible] rolling off.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a lot there. I'll start with the cash flow. We'll have reasonably good cash flow in '16 at the outlook levels. We'll cover our CapEx. Again, we're going to work hard to get that number down. We'll cover dividend. And I suspect end up with positive
componenttext: That's a lot there. I'll start with the cash flow. We'll have reasonably good cash flow in '16 at the outlook levels. We'll cover our CapEx. Again, we're going to work hard to get that number down. We'll cover dividend. And I suspect end up with positive cash flow above that. So we'll be able to maintain our balance sheet about where it is, if not strengthening it a bit more this year. Again, I'm not going to give you the '17 too much, but the same philosophy would hold in terms of the priorities of maintaining that. And in fact, maybe if we have to get to a point in '16 or '17, to use the strength of the balance sheet to protect the dividend, we will. And I've commented before about that. And I think, '16, if the outlook numbers were -- we feel pretty good about in terms of cash flow, et cetera. Mike, can handle the other one?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just a little bit on the buy segment. We did talk a lot about sales change and not much about the profit change by segment. so here's what I would say around that. So let's just backtrack a little bit and look at 2015. What happened in 2015 to decrem
componenttext: Yes, just a little bit on the buy segment. We did talk a lot about sales change and not much about the profit change by segment. so here's what I would say around that. So let's just backtrack a little bit and look at 2015. What happened in 2015 to decremental. Construction had an awesome year. Decrementals in construction were 10%. So their sales were down about $2.8 billion. Their profit was down less than $300 million. And that was despite this legal charge that they got in the end of the year. So very good year on managing decrementals. Resource Industries, their decrementals were 36%. And I think that was a little over our target range and partly because despite sales going down, we spent more there on R&D. I mean it's a business that we think will be good for the long term, and we needed to spend investment money in R&D there. And in fact, we did. Energy & Transportation, they had decrementals of 24%, which I think given the mix of what was down for them, if you look at how much of their was down because of oil and gas, which tended to be above-average margin business, 24%, I think for them, is pretty good. In total for the company, and again, this is excluding restructuring, we had decrementals of about 20%. That's kind of what we've got baked into next year. I won't comment so much -- I mean, overall, 20%. I won't comment so much on ROS by segment. I mean like Resource Industries, for example. Their at or below their breakeven point right now. So the ROS number, I think, is probably less meaningful than the decremental. I think throughout the company, we're working on delivering decent decrementals and a big cost reduction that we have planned for next year, both on material cost, variable or variable costs in total and the big restructuring should help all the segments. So I'm not going to give ROS guidance, but I would say that certainly, as a company, I don't think any of our segments would be big outliers here. We'll be at or better than our kind of target decrementals.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Ann Duignan.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Ann Duignan.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is just is a little bit more big picture. Given the strength of the dollar and the weak emerging markets economic activity that we're seeing around the world, maybe specifically Canada and Latin America, is there any risk that we start t
componenttext: My first question is just is a little bit more big picture. Given the strength of the dollar and the weak emerging markets economic activity that we're seeing around the world, maybe specifically Canada and Latin America, is there any risk that we start to see equipment either used or new come flowing back into the U.S.? and then -- and thus putting incremental pressure in new equipment sales in the U.S.?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Ann. Actually, our EPA regulations have sort of held that to some degree because of the requirements of low sulfur fuel on machines that are produced in this country and the EPA emissions level. So there may be some of that, and we worried a
componenttext: Good morning, Ann. Actually, our EPA regulations have sort of held that to some degree because of the requirements of low sulfur fuel on machines that are produced in this country and the EPA emissions level. So there may be some of that, and we worried about that for a number of years. I think you're probably also alluding to the gray market that we said we have tended to see in times past where there's currencies that are a little bit out of align. I think the emissions thing, between us and Europe and Japan, for the most part in Canada, we'll be involved with that. There maybe some flow from the Canada here but Mexico is not in that. Latin America, I think will probably have some amelioration of what we've seen in historical levels of that, but it's something we would keep an eye on.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate that. And then the smoothing of the pension plan, going mark-to-market, I mean there's a reason why we smooth in the first place in order to reduce volatility. Are you concerned that moving to mark-to-market might end up adding to your
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate that. And then the smoothing of the pension plan, going mark-to-market, I mean there's a reason why we smooth in the first place in order to reduce volatility. Are you concerned that moving to mark-to-market might end up adding to your earnings volatility and through the course of the coming years?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ann, this is Mike. Couple of things. As I can't remember the year -- several years ago, we made a change to sunset or kind of main-defined benefit plans at the end of 2019. And along the way, we've been on a path to derisk the asset, the fund balance. We'
componenttext: Ann, this is Mike. Couple of things. As I can't remember the year -- several years ago, we made a change to sunset or kind of main-defined benefit plans at the end of 2019. And along the way, we've been on a path to derisk the asset, the fund balance. We've moved to more fixed incomes -- fixed income rather than equity, and that will likely continue. It's going to sunset again at the end of 2019. That doesn't completely take out volatility, but I think the combination of -- we stop adding people to that plan a long time ago. People in the plan are retiring. We're not adding people to it. It will stop at the end of '19 with a shift towards more fixed income. Probably be -- what we're thinking it would reduce the volatility somewhat, certainly won't take it away, wouldn't suggest that at all. But as more companies have moved to this method, I think when they have a year-end adjustment for this like we will at the end of this year, I think the market has done a decent job of understanding what's going on, and that it is -- what it is for what it is. So I don't think it will -- I mean our view anyway is that it's -- it wouldn't impact so much how people are viewing us, if there's a year-end adjustment. And we like the change because it better matches what's actually happening from an expense standpoint rather than spreading it over a year. So in the current year, for example, and I said this before, this is not a big, unique OTO item that's happening in the year. It's taking out losses from prior years that Were masking operating results in the current year. That's our view anyway.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know we're out of time. But just, where will we be and what inning will you be by the end of '16 on restructuring? When will be 100% done? Or do we have costs into '17 and '18?
componenttext: I know we're out of time. But just, where will we be and what inning will you be by the end of '16 on restructuring? When will be 100% done? Or do we have costs into '17 and '18?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll probably have some costs in '17, and the plan that we announced last September, I think, the last parts of it, I think we would expect to lap up sometime in '18. And thank you all for joining us. We'll talk to you again at the end of the first qua
componenttext:
We'll probably have some costs in '17, and the plan that we announced last September, I think, the last parts of it, I think we would expect to lap up sometime in '18. 
And thank you all for joining us. We'll talk to you again at the end of the first quarter.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. This does conclude today's conference call. You may disconnect your phone lines at this time, and have a wonderful day. Thank you for your participation.
componenttext: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. This does conclude today's conference call. You may disconnect your phone lines at this time, and have a wonderful day. Thank you for your participation.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Caterpillar full Year and 4Q 2015 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Mike DeWalt. Sir, the floor is yours.
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Caterpillar full Year and 4Q 2015 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Mike DeWalt. Sir, the floor is yours.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our year-end earnings call. I'm Mike DeWalt, Caterpillar's Vice President of Finance Services.On the call with me this morning, we have Doug Oberhelman, our Chairman and CEO; and Brad Halverson
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our year-end earnings call. I'm Mike DeWalt, Caterpillar's Vice President of Finance Services.
On the call with me this morning, we have Doug Oberhelman, our Chairman and CEO; and Brad Halverson, our Group President and CFO.
Now this morning, we're going to do the call similar to what we did last October. We'll be going through a short slide deck before we get to the Q&A. And if you don't have it yet, the slide deck, it's available on our website at caterpillar.com, and it's with the conference call webcast link.
This call is copyrighted by Caterpillar Inc., any use, recording or transmission of any portion of the call is strictly prohibited. If you'd like a copy of today's call transcript, we will be posting that in the Investors section of our caterpillar.com website, and it will be in the section labeled Results Webcast.
This morning, we'll be discussing forward-looking information that certainly involves risks and uncertainties and assumptions that could cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking information. A discussion of some of those factors individually or in the aggregate that could make actual results differ materially from our projections, well, that can be found in our cautionary statements under Item 1A, which is risk factors, and our 10-K filed last February, and it's in the forward-looking statements language in today's financial release and near the front of this morning's slide deck.
In addition, a reconciliation of non-GAAP measures can also be found in today's financial release. And again, that's been posted on our website at caterpillar.com.
Okay. With that, let's get started. If I could ask you to pull out the slide deck and flip to Page 4 -- or I'm sorry, Page 3, and that's the agenda of our slide deck. I'll start this morning with a quick review of the fourth quarter and the full year of '15 and the outlook for 2016, and then I'll hand off to Doug, and he'll cover a few of the key points that we were trying to make in this morning's financial release.
So with that, let's flip to what would be Page 4 at the bottom of the slide deck. And this is the fourth quarter 2015 results versus fourth quarter 2004 (sic) [ 2014 ]. And you can see on here that sales and revenues are down $3.2 billion from $14.2 billion to $11 billion. That's a 23% drop. And I'll kind of talk about that 2 ways. First, about $2.7 billion of that was lower volume, selling fewer things, and most of that was lower end-user demand. About $400 million of it was related to reductions in dealer inventory. Price realization was negative in the quarter, about $124 million, and we did have a stronger dollar versus the fourth quarter of '14, which causes our sales outside the U.S. to translate into fewer dollars. And in this case, quarter-over-quarter, negative about $400 million. So that's the $3.2 billion. If you look at that by segment, the biggest decline was Energy & Transportation. It was off $1.8 billion. About 8 -- $0.8 billion of that was CI, construction, and about half of that, a little more than half of that was where the dealer inventory impact was most concentrated, and then about $0.5 billion was Resource Industries. And again, that's mostly mining. So the decline was across the board, but a bit more concentration -- concentrated quarter-over-quarter in Energy & Transportation. And I think given what's happened to oil prices over the course of the past year, that's probably not a big surprise.
Now the profit impact of those changes or that decline in sales volume was about $940 million negative. The next largest item quarter-over-quarter is restructuring costs, and they were negative $585 million. They went from $97 million in the fourth quarter a year ago to $682 million this year. And a lot of that increase is a result of the fairly significant actions that we announced last September and are in the middle of implementing right now. Costs, though, were favorable, about $461 million, and that's pretty much all-in, excluding restructuring versus a year ago. So that's good news.
Now taxes, I know it's probably a little hard to follow what's happening with taxes. It was a very low kind of all-in tax impact in both quarters. The rate this year is a little lower than last year, and we had $85 million of favorable tax items in the fourth quarter of '14 and $77 million in the fourth quarter of '15. So a little bit hard to follow, but not a massive impact quarter-over-quarter.
If we look at the profit numbers on the table up above, all-in profit in the fourth quarter a year ago was $1.23. We actually had a loss of $0.15 in the fourth quarter of '15, and a lot of that was because of the significant restructuring costs. So the all-in change was a decline of $1.38 a share. Excluding the restructuring costs in '14, the fourth quarter was $1.35. The fourth quarter of '15 was $0.74, and we were down $0.61. We continue to report our results both with and without restructuring costs. We think it's important to help you kind of understand what's going on in the business. So that's the fourth quarter.
Let's flip to Page 5. That's the full year. It was obviously a tough year for us in 2015. Sales were off $8.2 billion. The vast majority of that was lower sales volume, but the stronger dollar impacted the full year in kind of the same way it did the quarter. In terms of segments, Energy & Transportation was the largest decliner at $3.8 billion. That was oil, rail, electric power. So fairly widespread within E&T. Construction Industries was down $2.8 billion and Resource Industries, $1.4 billion. So from a profit standpoint, all in, we were $5.88 in 2014. All in, including restructuring, we dropped to $3.50 in 2015. And that's a decline of $2.38 a share. More than all of that is the decline in volume. If you take out restructuring costs, we were $6.38 in '14 and $4.64 in '15, down $1.74. And I think the story for '15 is big sales headwind, $8.2 billion, but we worked really hard on lowering costs. We took significant restructuring actions, and new restructuring actions began in the third quarter. Our costs were about $520 million favorable, and that's net of about $350 million of unfavorable cost absorption. So let me explain that a little bit.
In 2014, sales were pretty flat with 2013, not a big change. So inventory didn't change much. It was down $400 million in '14. In '15 -- so inventory absorption wasn't a big deal in '14. In '15, inventory declined $2.5 billion. So that's $2.1 billion more than it did in 2015, and there's a pretty significant cost impact to that sizable a decline in inventory, order of magnitude, $350 million. And so without that, costs would have been even more favorable.
Share count was positive to profit year-over-year, about $0.16 a share, and that's -- a lot of that is the full year impact of the significant repurchases we did in '14 and a partial year impact of the repurchases that we did in '15. Overall, bottom line, all in on tax, not much change year-over-year. So that's the full year. And if you take out the restructuring costs, I would just mention that our decremental operating profit margins were about 20%, and we would consider that to be pretty good performance. It's better than our 25% to 30% target.
So let's flip to the next page, Page 6. Now Page 6 is a little discussion on how we did versus our outlook. And in this case, we're -- since so much transpired over the year, we're kind of taking a long look back. How did we do versus what we told you we thought we would do a year ago right now in our year-end call for '14? And then how did we come out versus the outlook that we had in place at the end of October, the last conference call that we had, the third quarter financial release?
And so if you look down the numbers, in January a year ago, we were expecting sales and revenues this year to be $50 billion, profit per share to be $4.60, restructuring costs to be only another $150 million, and then profit per share, excluding those restructuring costs, to be around $4.75.
Now what we actually had was sales and revenues that were $47 billion, and that's in the third column, which were $3 billion below where we thought they would be when we started the year. And I think everything that's happened with oil prices, commodities, in general, increased weakness in China, most of the sales decline that we actually had in '15, we'd anticipated in that outlook. We were down from that about $3 billion. Profit per share is lower by $1.10, and quite a bit of that is restructuring costs were a lot higher. And again, that's because we announced pretty substantial new actions in September. So excluding restructuring costs, we were at $4.64, and that's $0.11 a share shy of where our outlook was when we started the year. And I think our view would be, on a $3 billion sales decline, even given all the puts and takes, that's pretty good performance.
Now versus the last outlook that we provided in late October of 2015, we said our outlook was going to be about $48 billion, and we kind of clarified that a little further as somewhere in the range of $47 billion and $48 billion. We were looking at profit per share of $3.70, and that included $800 million of restructuring costs. And then excluding restructuring, we were looking at $4.60. Well, what we actually did was a little worse on sales. It's been a continuing challenging environment. Profit per share was lower, and that's largely because we had more restructuring costs than we expected at the time. Excluding restructuring, we ended up the year at $4.64. Actually, a little ahead of our outlook. Now I've seen a few of this morning's analyst reports. And for sure, we did not have the tax extenders in our previous outlook. So that was an unanticipated benefit for us. And several analyst reports, I think, have picked that up. The flip side of that is we also had a fairly sizable charge for a legal matter in our fourth quarter. We didn't expect that either, and it really wasn't related to operations, if you will, in the quarter. And those 2 items about offset each other. So I would say, all in, despite lower sales, we did a little bit better than our outlook, and we're pretty pleased with that.
So let's talk about 2016. A lot going on in 2016. So let's flip to Page 7. First, we'll do sales and revenues. It looks to us like another tough year. We don't really forecast -- we're not forecasting any real improvement in the overall world economy. We're not banking on commodities getting better. And as a result of that, we're looking at $40 billion to $44 billion in sales and revenues. A midpoint there is about $42 billion. Now that is about $3.5 billion below where we were thinking last October when we gave a preliminary outlook. And I think that's probably not too surprising to most of you with the continued slide in oil prices to down around $30 a share, and I would say continuing concern and worry around emerging markets, particularly China.
So as we look at next year and what we think will happen with sales or what we're expecting, another down year for Energy & Transportation, down 10% to 15%. Now quite a bit of that decline is around timing. So we knew oil prices were coming down last year. We expected that to weaken pretty substantially in 2014, and it did. But most of that reduction was in the second half of the year. We started 2014 with a pretty sizable backlog. And we sold out of the backlog for the first half of the year in Energy & Transportation, particularly in the reciprocating engines for the -- for oil customers. So if you looked at Energy & Transportation at their first half of '14, they -- or I'm sorry, the first half of '15, they were only down 6% versus the prior year. Second half of the year was down 27%. That is kind of how we thought it would play in. It's what we signaled at the beginning of the year, stronger first half, weaker second half. And now we see kind of that level of business continuing on with the recent oil and gas business out on into 2015.
Construction Industries, we're looking at being down 5% to 10%. In Resource Industries, down another 15% to 20%. Now on Resource Industries, the bad news is it looks like it's down another 15% to 20%. That's really a tough business in mining, very few orders. Many of our customers are in sort of challenged financial conditions. But what I would say is sales of new equipment in that number are quite low. You never want to say never about upside and downside risk, but there's so little new equipment in there. I think it's fair to say the downside risk is somewhat limited.
In terms of profit per share, we put in a table here, and this is a table that was in our financial release. There's a lot of moving parts. So I thought it would help to walk through it piece by piece. So if you look at our outlook for 2016, all in, profit per share, we're looking at $3.50, and that includes restructuring costs and that includes pension changes that we are making.
We're making a change in accounting principle. It relates to our defined benefit plans primarily. It's positive to our results about $0.50 a share. And the way you want to think about this is we're moving from an accounting method that smooths actuarial gains and losses from prior years into current year results. And we're moving from that to a method that's kind of more mark-to-market and will closer -- will be a closer representation of what our current year costs really are. And that's favorable, about $425 million in and of itself, and that's about $0.50 a share. We also have another $400 million or so of restructuring costs in our outlook, and that's about $0.50. So all-in, excluding restructuring costs, we're at $4 a share. So that's the outlook for 2016 on sales and profit. In terms of profit, the negatives are lower sales as we go into 2016 from $47 billion down to the midpoint would be $42 billion. So at the midpoint, that's a $5 billion profit drop, offset by considerable cost reduction. A lot of that as a result of the restructuring actions that we started to put in place last September.
So with that, I'll turn the floor over to Doug Oberhelman.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Good morning, everyone. And I do want to make a few key points as I look back on '15 and forward into '16. Mike said it. It was a very tough year, but when you think about everything that happened, the challenges, the chaos sometime during the year
componenttext:
Okay. Good morning, everyone. And I do want to make a few key points as I look back on '15 and forward into '16. Mike said it. It was a very tough year, but when you think about everything that happened, the challenges, the chaos sometime during the year with events around the world, a year ago today, we were expecting $50 billion in sales. We ended up at $47 billion. That $3 billion is quite a drop, but we really only reduced our profit per share outside of restructuring by $0.11. And as Mike said, there's a lot involved in that, up and down. But basically, I'm pretty pleased with cost management, the restructuring actions we took in the fourth quarter. Actually, they were more aggressive than we had planned and announced, and we took about $100 million more because of it, but that will suit us up well for 2016. So our team really did a good job, and I -- it's tough to say, but I -- we're getting used to cycles here. 2009 volume at $32 billion, we doubled the company in 3 years in 2012.
