componenttext: And then the carryover cost, the Slide #7, when you say on track for over $2 billion, I'm not sure if that's an annualized number, but assuming it's a $2 billion run rate exiting the year, looking how the quarters play out or really first quarter, second quarter, second half, are you implying a carryover cost savings of $1 billion?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So that's 2016 versus 2015 costs. And we start -- a lot of that started coming out very early in 2016. Our first quarter was quite favorable. Our second quarter was even more favorable. So I think we will probably end the year with -- as you look for
componenttext: Yes. So that's 2016 versus 2015 costs. And we start -- a lot of that started coming out very early in 2016. Our first quarter was quite favorable. Our second quarter was even more favorable. So I think we will probably end the year with -- as you look forward, based on the timing of the cost reduction, a tailwind, but I don't think it would be $1 billion.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Jamie Cook.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Jamie Cook.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Crédit Suisse. A couple of clarifications. One, Mike, in the press release, and I think in your commentary, you implied Solar was flat with the first quarter, up from the beginning of the year, but you also talked about some customers pushing out orders
componenttext: Crédit Suisse. A couple of clarifications. One, Mike, in the press release, and I think in your commentary, you implied Solar was flat with the first quarter, up from the beginning of the year, but you also talked about some customers pushing out orders into '17. So I'm just wondering, is it -- is the backlog flat because of pushouts? Are you actually seeing order activity? And then my second question is for Doug. Doug, I mean, you've talked historically about managing to sort of targeted $3.50 trough-ish EPS. As we sit here today, given the markets don't seem to be getting better, we're already at $3.55 this year, is that off the table? Or do you think there are incremental levers that you could pull to manage profitability as we think out over the next 12 months?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start with that on the Solar piece, and then I'll turn it over to Doug. But on Solar, what we see customers pushing out a little bit is the timing of some maintenance. And that doesn't have usually as long a backlog as the new products. So probably i
componenttext: I'll start with that on the Solar piece, and then I'll turn it over to Doug. But on Solar, what we see customers pushing out a little bit is the timing of some maintenance. And that doesn't have usually as long a backlog as the new products. So probably impacts this year's sales a little quicker than it does backlog, just by the nature of it. I think the reason that we made a comment on Solar backlog is because everybody's concerned about it. And we're just trying to reassure everyone that there -- what they're selling, they're replacing with new orders. That's not fallen off a cliff or off the table. And the gas business just keeps on chugging along. So I'll turn it over to Doug.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. In terms of the -- of your trough earnings question, I think your questions are reasonable one to assume. As you say, without all the restructuring costs, we're at $3.55. And as Mike said, you take $0.08 back, we're a little bit above that even. B
componenttext: Thanks. In terms of the -- of your trough earnings question, I think your questions are reasonable one to assume. As you say, without all the restructuring costs, we're at $3.55. And as Mike said, you take $0.08 back, we're a little bit above that even. But certainly, around 40, where we are now, that's a reasonable assumption to go after. And that's where we're going to fight to try and find a bottom, if that's what we're fighting in the future.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Brad Halverson. I might just add a quick point, Doug. The trough earnings number has been stated between $2.50 and $3.50. I'd say, if you look at how -- and I would say the sales decline modeled in those scenarios would not have been as severe as
componenttext: This is Brad Halverson. I might just add a quick point, Doug. The trough earnings number has been stated between $2.50 and $3.50. I'd say, if you look at how -- and I would say the sales decline modeled in those scenarios would not have been as severe as what we've experienced in the 4-year trend. So going from above 60 down to 40, we've been absolutely trying to stay ahead of the process to be prepared, if things did not get better. If we were not staying ahead, quite frankly, there is no way we could have done $2 billion of cost reduction this year to offset some of the price pressures and the drop in volume. And we really like our mid-cycle numbers. Everybody wants to know when we're going to start recovering in that trend towards mid-cycle, but we still need to be prepared for what could happen in the next -- in the short term on the downside. And so we've talked about kind of 25% to 30% decremental. I would say we're still committed to that. I would also say that we're being extremely directive in the things that we fund, things like digital, which will be up significantly this year over the last year, things like funding the businesses that we believe have the highest opportunity to improve the value of the company and it -- and our operating profit after capital charge, which we call OPACC in the medium term. So we want to fund those industries, which we think are attractive for us and where we play well. And things that are not as attractive are the places that we look first to cut. So we're still in that process, and we're still preparing to stay ahead of the game. And I would say that, if required, we would be ready.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right, Brad. And I would just come back to the incremental-decremental pull-throughs on the way up and the way down that have served us pretty well going back to '09 on the way up from $30 billion to $66 billion and then on the way down from $
componenttext: Yes, that's right, Brad. And I would just come back to the incremental-decremental pull-throughs on the way up and the way down that have served us pretty well going back to '09 on the way up from $30 billion to $66 billion and then on the way down from $66 billion to $40.25 billion this year. We've managed to stay inside of those targets all the way up and down. And I think that's probably one of the single biggest differences we've been able to accomplish from prior deep slowdowns in the 40% range top line is we've got everybody targeting those. And that's what we -- where we go after with, our cost reductions. And as Brad said, our capital allocations, and in those businesses, we really want to stay in and thrive in long term.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Jerry Revich.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Jerry Revich.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Goldman Sachs. Mike, you spoke about roughly $2 billion or so in applied dealer inventory reductions, which I think is mostly in the back half of this year. Can you just give us a flavor for the mix between construction and resource? Is there any reg
componenttext: It's Goldman Sachs. Mike, you spoke about roughly $2 billion or so in applied dealer inventory reductions, which I think is mostly in the back half of this year. Can you just give us a flavor for the mix between construction and resource? Is there any regional color that you can give us where you expect inventories to come down? And as we enter '17, do you think we're at normalized dealer inventory levels for the current demand environment?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of things. $2 billion is a little too high a number. It's probably more like year-over-year $1.5 billion, and it's probably split 2/3 construction, 1/3 resource in that sort of ballpark. And in terms of adequate levels, I mean, I've tried to a
componenttext: So a couple of things. $2 billion is a little too high a number. It's probably more like year-over-year $1.5 billion, and it's probably split 2/3 construction, 1/3 resource in that sort of ballpark. And in terms of adequate levels, I mean, I've tried to address this point. I think adequate levels is a little bit of a moving target around delivery performance. So again, if we were able to cut delivery performance in half from where it's at now, dealers would feel comfortable holding less inventory. If our delivery -- if -- let's say things ticked up, orders ticked up, the market is heated up, and let's say we were -- we had trouble keeping up, that would concern dealers and they would order even more. They would want to hold even more. But just the opposite is happening right now. We have excellent delivery performance. They can get pretty much what they need when their customers need it. And so that's causing them to hold or want to hold less. And the more -- the better we do with Lean, the more that will probably be the case. So I would -- I'm trying to stress a point. I don't think dealer inventories are excessive. I mean, there's a reasonable range, but I think they will come down over the second half of the year.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you're talking about the major restructuring changes. As we think about the eventual recovery, can you update us on how you're thinking about incremental margins and recovery given the change in the manufacturing footprint?
componenttext: Okay. And you're talking about the major restructuring changes. As we think about the eventual recovery, can you update us on how you're thinking about incremental margins and recovery given the change in the manufacturing footprint?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it should be -- and Doug has talked about this quite a bit, on the way up. We previously kind of had a 25% incremental target. But I think, while we've not quantified it, certainly our expectation is that the first chunk of what goes up, it would ce
componenttext: Well, it should be -- and Doug has talked about this quite a bit, on the way up. We previously kind of had a 25% incremental target. But I think, while we've not quantified it, certainly our expectation is that the first chunk of what goes up, it would certainly be at a higher rate than that.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Robert Wertheimer.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Robert Wertheimer.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Barclays Bank. Construction margins are really quite impressive given negative pricing and given volumes that are [indiscernible] in LatAm and maybe low cycle elsewhere. Can you see steep falls from here? Do you think that's bottoming? And I'm curiou
componenttext: It's Barclays Bank. Construction margins are really quite impressive given negative pricing and given volumes that are [indiscernible] in LatAm and maybe low cycle elsewhere. Can you see steep falls from here? Do you think that's bottoming? And I'm curious if you have any view or willing to share any view rather on the structural margin upside? Did you actually get a healthy market given what you're doing in low cycle?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's a good question. I think our construction business is a great example of how are managing for maximum OPACC, operating profit less of capital charge, can work. They've been on this path to maximize OPACC for the last few years, which is in --
componenttext: Yes. That's a good question. I think our construction business is a great example of how are managing for maximum OPACC, operating profit less of capital charge, can work. They've been on this path to maximize OPACC for the last few years, which is in -- which is fundamentally around figuring out where you make the most money and where you don't, fixing where you don't and reinvesting in where you do to increase sales. So that's oversimplification of it. But that's worked. I mean, they've also taken out -- I mean, they're also very cost-cautious. They've taken out costs. But relative to where we think a trough, a mid-cycle, a peak would be, they're not as bad off of as, say, oil or rail or mining. But I think there's plenty of upside for them. North America is still well below the peak. Brazil is, wow, so far down you can hardly see it. So I think there's plenty of scope for improvement. And based on the work that these guys have done to figure out where to invest to drive OPACC, I think there's still plenty of upside left for them.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you see signs of stabilization in North American construction? I mean, we're -- as you said, we're well below the prior peak and some of [indiscernible], do you think there's material downside chances there? Or are you seeing stable?
componenttext: Do you see signs of stabilization in North American construction? I mean, we're -- as you said, we're well below the prior peak and some of [indiscernible], do you think there's material downside chances there? Or are you seeing stable?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't see material downside at the moment, frankly. We've seen so many states step up with bond issues. We've seen many states step up with tax increases for infrastructure spending. Anecdotally, a lot of our customers are busy across the country.
componenttext: Yes. I don't see material downside at the moment, frankly. We've seen so many states step up with bond issues. We've seen many states step up with tax increases for infrastructure spending. Anecdotally, a lot of our customers are busy across the country. 2% growth rate of -- the 1.5% to 2% does not spur a lot of investment, but there's enough going on to tell me that we're not facing a cliff here, unless there's some outside event of some kind that occurs. So I don't see it collapsing, or as you said, a big falloff. I would sure like to see the growth increase based on increased economic activity.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Brad. I'll just make one other comment. We're not going to give you kind of an incremental number this year to plot in. We've talked about it being fairly high. One thing I would say for reference is that the vast majority of costs we've taken out
componenttext: This is Brad. I'll just make one other comment. We're not going to give you kind of an incremental number this year to plot in. We've talked about it being fairly high. One thing I would say for reference is that the vast majority of costs we've taken out, we would not add back. So as we restructure, as we change things, if you think that there are costs that we're ready to add back that we've taken out, I would say outside of some very minor amounts, most of those costs we're not going to add back. So as we add period costs in an upturn relative to our incrementals, it would be focused really around our OPACC improvement agenda of those places we want to invest more because we think there's a significant amount of value. And so that will probably drive that incremental discussion when we get to that point.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from Timothy Thein.
componenttext: The next question is coming from Timothy Thein.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Citigroup. So the first is on the energy part of E&T, and I guess, specifically in well servicing where I would think you'd see -- would see recovery first in a more stable oil price environment. So the question just revolves around where the service comp
componenttext: Citigroup. So the first is on the energy part of E&T, and I guess, specifically in well servicing where I would think you'd see -- would see recovery first in a more stable oil price environment. So the question just revolves around where the service companies that you and your dealers speak to. Where they sit from a sentiment standpoint on CapEx? There's been some comments of some restocking of consumables, but just curious what you're seeing out there.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think probably the best way to say that is where oil prices are today is probably not enough to drive a lot of incremental investment there. I think the thing you'll see first is the idle fleets being put back to work, particularly around drilling,
componenttext: Yes. I think probably the best way to say that is where oil prices are today is probably not enough to drive a lot of incremental investment there. I think the thing you'll see first is the idle fleets being put back to work, particularly around drilling, before we see some investment. So I -- I mean -- oil prices this morning, I guess, were in a $42-plus range. We're probably still ways away from that.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. Maybe the second one on Cat Financial. I don't know if Brad is still around. But the question relates to the penetration rate in the quarter. I think new retail financing is now eclipsed 30% and hasn't been there, I don't think, post the fin
componenttext: Okay. Got it. Maybe the second one on Cat Financial. I don't know if Brad is still around. But the question relates to the penetration rate in the quarter. I think new retail financing is now eclipsed 30% and hasn't been there, I don't think, post the financial crisis. So I'm wondering is that a shift in the underlying business mix that's driving that? Or is that perhaps more of a kind of a strategy shift for Cat? Or maybe you could speak to that.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Mike. So Cat Financial is always trying to increase their share, just like every other part of our business. They're trying to increase their market share, if you will, the percentage of deals that they do versus their competitors. And they'v
componenttext: Yes. This is Mike. So Cat Financial is always trying to increase their share, just like every other part of our business. They're trying to increase their market share, if you will, the percentage of deals that they do versus their competitors. And they've actually done a very good job over the last couple of years in increasing that. And I think that's what you're -- I think that's what you're seeing. I mean, the limit on that is you certainly don't want to do shaky deals. I mean, you don't want to sacrifice credit quality to do it, but you want to work very closely with the dealers, with the customers and capture as much market share as he can.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Brad. I'll add on to that. We're very proud of the people at Cat Financial and how they run that business very independently in partnership with our product groups, but very independently. And so you'll see our allowance being very well maint
componenttext: Yes. This is Brad. I'll add on to that. We're very proud of the people at Cat Financial and how they run that business very independently in partnership with our product groups, but very independently. And so you'll see our allowance being very well maintained at around 1 25 -- or 1.25% past dues, similar trend at 2.93%, fairly close to previous quarter and below historical average. And we have grown our share there. But one thing I want to comment on, which we had a few questions come in on, there is pressure in the used equipment market. It's probably down 2% or 3% from the last quarter. It's probably down 5% to 10%, if you look from a year ago. We carry a little over $600 million of used equipment both from repossessions and residuals. Still pretty well behaved. We had a gain last year. We had a very small loss this quarter. And so we don't see any big issues in that regard. But I would tell you that, that is an area that does have some pressure and that we're watching, but it's, at this point, very well maintained.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Steven Fisher.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Steven Fisher.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's UBS. Just a question on the restructuring. How anticipatory would you say is the incremental $150 million in the quarter versus just kind of reflecting what current conditions warrant? In other words, you talked in your question 8 in the back about t
componenttext: It's UBS. Just a question on the restructuring. How anticipatory would you say is the incremental $150 million in the quarter versus just kind of reflecting what current conditions warrant? In other words, you talked in your question 8 in the back about too early -- to really say what impact Brexit would have. But would this incremental restructuring be intended to mitigate a potential slowdown in -- from the U.K. Brexit and a potential slowing in U.S. nonres construction activity? Or would you might want to do more restructuring, if those things play out?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that's a good question. I wouldn't relate it specifically to anyone of those. I think you have to look at it in the aggregate. And Brad made actually a really important point a couple of minutes ago, and that's we are trying to get -- we don't have a c
componenttext: So that's a good question. I wouldn't relate it specifically to anyone of those. I think you have to look at it in the aggregate. And Brad made actually a really important point a couple of minutes ago, and that's we are trying to get -- we don't have a crystal ball. We don't know what's going to happen in the marketplace, but we want to be positioned to deal with it, if it does happen. So I would say that over the course of the past quarter, we're a little more negative on the world economy. And the Brexit, the Turkey, the elections, oil price. You name it. All of that contributes. And we're less bullish on second half sales because of that. And whatever impact that would have in the future, we're trying to get ahead of that with additional cost reduction. So I would say it's us trying to get ahead of the potential, not what we actually know and not specifically related to any one of those items.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful, Mike. And then in terms of the mining profitability, the $163 million loss was a step down in the quarter compared to Q1. I mean, how are you thinking about where that goes from here? How contained can your restructuring actions keep
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful, Mike. And then in terms of the mining profitability, the $163 million loss was a step down in the quarter compared to Q1. I mean, how are you thinking about where that goes from here? How contained can your restructuring actions keep those losses going forward?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Hopefully, this is the -- hopefully, this is the worst quarter we'll see. I think embedded within our outlook we see it getting a little bit better. Second quarter, price-wise, was deteriorated a little bit from the first quarter. And when you get th
componenttext: Yes. Hopefully, this is the -- hopefully, this is the worst quarter we'll see. I think embedded within our outlook we see it getting a little bit better. Second quarter, price-wise, was deteriorated a little bit from the first quarter. And when you get the numbers, we're talking a change, quarter-to-quarter of a couple of hundred million, not for pricing, but in total for them. Costs were a little higher because of some inventory adjustments. Just kind of normal surplus and excess inventory. And then we had a little negative inventory absorption for RI. They took out inventory in the second quarter. That hurt a little bit. They are certainly a part of the extra cost reduction that we're going after in the second half of the year. When I talked a little bit about first half, second half, we think their sales are going to be up a little bit in the second half of the year. So I think that a combination of extra cost reduction and a few more sales hopefully will make this the -- make the second quarter the worst of the year.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Stephen Volkmann.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Stephen Volkmann.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Jefferies. Doug, I'm going to take you up in the sense you mentioned infrastructure trends getting a little bit better. How big of an opportunity is that for Cat? How much of revenue might that be? Or how should we think about sizing that going forwa
componenttext: It's Jefferies. Doug, I'm going to take you up in the sense you mentioned infrastructure trends getting a little bit better. How big of an opportunity is that for Cat? How much of revenue might that be? Or how should we think about sizing that going forward?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to tell, actually. The Highway Bill -- the Federal Transportation Act that was passed last year in itself did not increase overall funding an awful lot in this country. It held it at inflation, plus a little bit, but it did get a -- did give it
componenttext: It's hard to tell, actually. The Highway Bill -- the Federal Transportation Act that was passed last year in itself did not increase overall funding an awful lot in this country. It held it at inflation, plus a little bit, but it did get a -- did give it 5 years. I think as most states have recovered from their fiscal problems the last few years, they're starting to recognize the needs for infrastructure. And we're seeing that. If there's any impact, and I've said this all year long, from that transportation act of last year, it's going to be a '17 event. We might feel it. I don't think it would move the needle a great deal, but we would certainly feel it. It's hard to quantify until states start lining up for their matching funds. So there's quite a big effort under way to get that done as well. So we'll just have to see it play out. It's certainly going to be a positive, but I would doubt we'd see it move the needle in a big way in '17. But we'd feel it.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. And then Mike, maybe just a couple of quick modeling questions. How do we think about taxes going forward with the various changes you've had? And then what's the normal level of short-term incentive compensation, if we're thinking
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. And then Mike, maybe just a couple of quick modeling questions. How do we think about taxes going forward with the various changes you've had? And then what's the normal level of short-term incentive compensation, if we're thinking into the out years?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two good questions, Steve. First, on taxes. All in, we're looking at a 25% tax rate this year, but that is a little lower because of all the restructuring, which has tended to be in a little higher tax jurisdictions. And so the restructuring is attracting
componenttext: Two good questions, Steve. First, on taxes. All in, we're looking at a 25% tax rate this year, but that is a little lower because of all the restructuring, which has tended to be in a little higher tax jurisdictions. And so the restructuring is attracting somewhere around, I think, low 30s -- 34%, I think. So excluding restructuring, it will vary a little bit by quarter, depending upon how much restructuring there is, but probably around 27%, excluding restructuring. And then what's normal on incentive pay, I'm going to qualify it a little bit here. It depends on how many employees we have because it scales, if you look at it in terms of dollars. But based on the number of employees we have right now, if we were to pay everyone at a 1.0 payout, which we would consider to be normal in a normal year, you're looking at something in the order of magnitude of, let's say, a rough number, 8 50.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Joe O'Dea.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Joe O'Dea.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Vertical Research. First question, just on the rail side. It sounded like, from a geographic standpoint, that the softness that you would have seen year-over-year was more international. But could you just give a little bit of commentary on kind of w
componenttext: It's Vertical Research. First question, just on the rail side. It sounded like, from a geographic standpoint, that the softness that you would have seen year-over-year was more international. But could you just give a little bit of commentary on kind of what the North America trends are like for you? Incremental softness with North America rail flat year-over-year, just how kind of stable you think that is as you start to think about it more kind of downside risk, upside risk and how stable those North America trends are?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joe, I feel a little bad here. I didn't -- I've tried to prep a little on rail, but I didn't do it by region. So can't talk too much about North America specifics. Sorry. I'm just not further up to speed. What I would say is, we're looking for a bit bette
componenttext: Joe, I feel a little bad here. I didn't -- I've tried to prep a little on rail, but I didn't do it by region. So can't talk too much about North America specifics. Sorry. I'm just not further up to speed. What I would say is, we're looking for a bit better rail sales in the back half of this year. Remember, we've just introduced our new locomotive in midyear. And while sales aren't huge for that right now, kind of given the state of the overall industry, we certainly are going to sell some. So that's part of the increase in the back half of the year.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on resources, it seemed like in the first quarter, one of the challenges was aftermarket came in a little lighter than we would've expected to start off the year with the expectation that moving deeper into '16, that would improve. From a m
componenttext: Okay. And then on resources, it seemed like in the first quarter, one of the challenges was aftermarket came in a little lighter than we would've expected to start off the year with the expectation that moving deeper into '16, that would improve. From a margin standpoint, it didn't look like there was a mix benefit in the second quarter. But could you just talk about kind of sequential trends? What you're hearing from dealers? The scheduled rebuilds? It sounds like that's a little bit better. Did you see some improvement in aftermarket from first quarter to second quarter?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're hearing the dealers are booking a little -- a bit more. In fact, I verified that with our mining group last night. They are seeing -- dealers are seeing an uptick of bookings around rebuild. Haven't really hit our parts business quite get. But
componenttext:
Well, we're hearing the dealers are booking a little -- a bit more. In fact, I verified that with our mining group last night. They are seeing -- dealers are seeing an uptick of bookings around rebuild. Haven't really hit our parts business quite get. But hopefully, it will. And your synopsis of no big upturn in parts sales around mining is actually correct, at least so far. 
All righty. Well, I think we're at the top of the hour here. Actually, a minute or so over. So we'll conclude the call. Thank you very much.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. This does conclude today's conference call. You may disconnect your phone lines at this time, and have a wonderful day. Thank you for your participation.
componenttext: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. This does conclude today's conference call. You may disconnect your phone lines at this time, and have a wonderful day. Thank you for your participation.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Caterpillar 2Q 2016 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Mike DeWalt. Sir, the floor is yours.
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Caterpillar 2Q 2016 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Mike DeWalt. Sir, the floor is yours.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to our Second Quarter Earnings Call. I'm Mike DeWalt, Caterpillar's Vice President of Finance Services. And as usual, on the call with me this morning, we have our Chairman and CEO, Doug Oberhelman;
componenttext:
Thank you very much, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to our Second Quarter Earnings Call. I'm Mike DeWalt, Caterpillar's Vice President of Finance Services. And as usual, on the call with me this morning, we have our Chairman and CEO, Doug Oberhelman; and our Group President and CFO, Brad Halverson. 
Today, I'll start by walking you through a short slide deck, similar to what we've done over the past couple of quarters, and then we'll move on to the Q&A after that. 
So if you don't have the slide deck in front of you right now, it's available on our website, at caterpillar.com, in the Investors section. And it's where the webcast link was. 
This call is copyrighted by Caterpillar, Inc. And any use, recording or transmission of any portion of the call without the expressed written consent of Caterpillar is strictly prohibited. If you'd like a copy of today's call transcript, we will be posting it in the Investors section of our caterpillar.com website. And it'll be in the section labeled Results Webcast. 
If you go to Page 2 of this morning's slide deck, you'll see our forward-looking statements. This morning, we'll be discussing forward-looking information that involves risks, uncertainties and assumptions that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking information. 
In addition to Page 2 of the slide deck, discussions either individually or in the aggregate could make actual results to differ materially, can also be found in Cautionary Statements under Item 1A of our Form 10-K filed with the SEC and the forward-looking statements language in today's financial release. 
In addition, a reconciliation of non-GAAP measures used in both the financial release and this presentation can also be found in the financial release on our website and is also the back page of today's slide deck.
So with that, let's get started on the slide deck, and I would ask you to flip over to Page 4. It's the comparison of the second quarter 2016 with the second quarter of 2015. It has the key lines for the second quarter versus last year. Sales and revenues down about $2 billion. About half of that was Energy & Transportation, and the other half was split close to evenly between Resource Industries and Construction Industries. And I'll talk a little bit more about sales in a minute. 
And profit. The Primary drivers of the decline in profit from $1.31 to $0.93 a share this quarter, and excluding restructuring, $1.09, down from $1.40, so a $0.31 decline. 
By far, the biggest negative in the quarter was the decline in sales volume, and that included negative sales mix as more of the decline was in higher-margin products, like oil and gas. 
Price realization was also pretty a substantial negative in the quarter, and that was off $233 million. 
Now on the favorable side, below operating profit, other income and expense was a positive $156 million. And that was mostly all due to the absence of below operating profit exchange losses from a year ago. An important point, I think, to note about this second quarter was exchange had actually little impact on the quarter itself. 
And then the bottom, the most substantial positive in the quarter from a profit standpoint was cost reduction. Period and variable costs were favorable $670 million versus a year ago. And that just brings up the point here that we've been really focused on execution. That includes the cost reduction, but is not exclusively cost reduction. I mean, we've improved our market position as well in -- around the word, and in particular, in China as well. 
So let's switch onto the next page, Page 5. It's a discussion of sales and revenues. Again, the biggest sales decline in the quarter was in Energy & Transportation, just shy of $1 billion. We've been talking about this for the last year or so. The decline really started about midyear last year. So this second quarter is kind of the last, I think, of the big declines that we're going to see, particularly related to oil. First to first, second to second. By the time we got to the third quarter, and certainly by the time we got to the fourth quarter of last year, it was pretty much all baked in. In fact, I think by the time we get to the fourth quarter of this year, the comps will be a lot more like the prior year. So this should be the last quarter of declines in -- at least in this size. 
Resource Industries down about $600 million. And most of that decline was lower end-user demand and a little bit from pricing. I mean, mining is just -- continued to be a very challenged industry. Customers are pushing out replacement purchases. They're delaying as much repair as they can. And we see that in our sales. 
Now relative to kind of the trend, it's about flat with where we were in the first quarter. So no continuing deterioration from where we were last quarter, but down from a year ago. 
And then finally, Construction Industries, down just under $400 million. A little more than half of the decline was price realization, and it is a pretty tough pricing environment out there today in construction. And we see it everywhere. We see it in the U.S. We see it outside the U.S. 
Now a word about this, because I know it may seem to you like it's accelerating, but it's kind of not. It started going up about midyear last year; the sales variance, the discounting. And so we had negatives in the second half of last year. The first half of this year is comparing with a better period a year ago. So it looks like it's quite a bit of an increase. But it's not much of an increase actually from where we've been over the last 2 or 3 quarters. And I think as we go on and talk about this in the outlook, we kind of see it starting to flatten out. 
Sales were down in North America, Latin America. Europe, Africa and Middle East was pretty flat year-over-year. Europe up; Africa, Middle East down. And sales in Asia were actually up year-over-year despite price pressure. 
So that's a quick run through of sales. I know related to Energy & Transportation, there's a lot of concern around the turbine business, because it's been pretty strong for quite some time. Our -- just a couple of facts about that. We reported on the backlog last quarter, said it was up slightly from year-end. Second quarter of this year is about spot-on, where we were at the end of the quarter. So we're not seeing any deterioration there. It's a little early to talk about 2017, but all indications are the year is progressing pretty well. 
Oil is lower. Work backlog, sales around natural gas and natural gas pipelines are still pretty strong. Okay. So that's sales. 
Let's flip over to Page 6 and talk a little bit about the operating profit change and cost in particular. So this is the waterfall chart that we have actually in the release. No big new information on here outside of the release. It just highlights how well we've done on cost reduction. So in total, between variable and period, or you might call relatively fixed cost, we're down about $670 million. And that's gone a long way to offset the impact of lower volume and product mix. And you can see on here price realization, the negative $233 million. And actually, we've had more variable cost reduction, if you think material costs and efficiency and that type of thing. We've about offset the impact on price realization with that. 
So year-to-date, if we turn to the next page, just talk a little bit about what we've done on costs. So on the first quarter, between period costs and variable costs, we were down just under $0.5 billion. This quarter again was $670 million. So through the first half of the year, we've taken over $1.1 billion of cost out. If you look up at the top of this page, in the yellow bubble up there, what we're saying is we're on track, our expectations are that we'll get -- we'll end this year with well over $2 billion of cost reduction. And that's coming really in 3 sort of general buckets. The most significant is restructuring, and that is everything from combining office functions and reducing people to taking out manufacturing floor space and related costs. Material costs have also been favorable. And we've had a good track record on material costs over the past few years. I mean, we're down over $1 billion over the last few years. And it really comes from mostly design and sourcing-related cost reduction, and then important, but to a lesser degree, commodity-related cost reduction. And then everything else. It's everything from a bit lower short-term incentive pay based on lower results and then cost reductions throughout the company, every place we can find it, from -- everything from travel and entertainment expense to consulting spend. So wherever we can take money out, we're working really hard to do that. 
So bottom line, we're investing in the things we need to for the future, things like digital and really important product programs. Everything else, we're really trying to put a lid on and cut where we can. And the results have actually been pretty good. 
So let's flip over to the next page, that would be Page 8, talk a little bit about the outlook for the year. When we were sitting here a quarter ago, we were expecting sales in a range of $40 billion to $42 billion. So $41 billion as a midpoint. We've taken that down about -- from midpoint to midpoint, about $0.75 billion. And the gist of that is just everything that we're seeing in the economy today around the world, additional risk, everything from the results of the Brexit vote and the short-term uncertainties that causes, the trouble we've seen in Turkey, all the negative rhetoric around the U.S. elections, oil prices have come off a little over the last couple of months. It's not any one thing, I would say. It's -- and we've said this in the outlook. We have sluggish economic growth throughout the world in general, but not enough to drive growth in our end markets. And the news we've seen over the last few months is definitely not giving us more confidence. 
So the outlook for profit is $2.75 a share, and that's all in, excluding restructuring costs, which are going to be about $700 million now this year. Net of that, we're at about 300 -- or $3, I'm sorry -- $3.55 a share. And both on the top line and bottom line, our estimate is actually pretty close to the last consensus analyst estimates that we've seen. So we're pretty close to we think where the market is. 
Now one point about this outlook, and this is on -- in Q&A 11 in our release on Page 15. It has been negatively affected about $0.08 a share by taxes. So we hadn't made the change in how we're looking at taxes on our profit excluding restructuring cost. The outlook would have been $0.08 higher, which isn't too bad of performance considering $750 million decline in the top line. And I think it just goes back to the main theme of execution, cost reduction, doing everything we possibly can to keep the company strong and give us the ability to invest in the future. 
One last point I'll make about sales, and this might well be on your minds as well, and that's kind of the status of dealer inventory. We're pretty flat right now in dealer inventory with the year-end last year, but we think it's going to come down quite a bit over the next 2 quarters. And that's not entirely unusual. Last year, we had a reduction as well. Full year reduction in dealer inventory this year is probably going to be, not quite, but close to double what we did last year. And it's not so much -- and you've asked this question before, "Do we have a glut of inventory?" And I certainly would not describe it as that. I think one of the things that's happening out there is a little bit of our own doing, and it's around Lean. If you look at our delivery performance and the stability of our delivery performance dealers, it's actually improved quite a bit over the last 5 years. We're at a point now where dealers, we think, have a lot of confidence in our ability to deliver what they need and when they need it. And we think that's causing them to both order less -- so as our delivery times have come down in construction, our backlog comes down a little. I mean, think of it this way. This is an oversimplified example. But if we had delivery times that were one day, we wouldn't have much backlog. Dealers would order, and we would ship it. So I think one of the reasons that construction backlog is a little lower and one of the reasons that we're getting probably more aggressive dealer inventory declines is how well we're performing on Lean relative to delivery performance. We knew that was likely to happen in the scheme of things. It's a good thing. 
So let's move on to the next -- the outlook. Let's move on to the next page, and that's -- I think it's probably a good time to talk about first half versus second half. We're through half of the year. Probably time to reflect a little bit on how the second half of the year is likely to shape up. End-user demand should be a fair bit higher than the first half of the year. I mean, we have our sales, which we think are going to be $600 million to $700 million higher than the first half. And that does include some substantial dealer inventory reduction. And we have profit per share, excluding restructuring cost, up $0.09. With restructuring, it's down a little, and that's because of the extra cost for restructuring in the back half. 
So if you look at how the sales shape up, that 65 -- that $6.5 billion -- $0.65 billion increase in sales, Construction Industries is likely to be down a little bit. End-user demand, pretty flat. But because of dealer inventory reductions, their sales are likely to be a bit down. That's our forecast anyway. Resource Industries, just slightly up from the first half run rate and not a lot. No big changes there in terms of trends. And then Energy & Transportation is responsible essentially for the increase in sales. And that's a -- that is mostly seasonal pattern on some of the big project kind of sales that we have. Turbines, for example. And we expect a bit more sales out of rail in the back half of the year, particularly in the fourth quarter. 
In terms of profit, we have the $0.09 a share, better profit in the second half of the year than the first half. And the higher sales volume is the most significant reason for that. 
Pricing. Let's talk about this, and I touched on it a minute ago. We -- on a year-over-year basis, the negative impact of pricing ought to start easing a little bit. And that's because we really saw a kick-up midyear last year. And first half versus second half though, forget about last year, we don't see much change in the pricing environment. 
Inventory cost absorption will be modest negative in the back half of the year. We're looking at taking inventory down $500 million, $600 million -- our own inventory, not dealer inventory, down $500 million, $600 million in the back half of the year. It'll be a little hit to profit, but positive for cash flow. We'll also -- we also had some sale of security gains in the second quarter for financial services division and for the insurance portion of that. And we're not expecting that to repeat in the second half. 
Cost overall, we think, will be fairly neutral first half to second half. We do have additional period cost reduction that we're looking at in the second half of the year, but with kind of low seasonal cost in the first quarter and probably a little bit of efficiency negative, production is going to come down because of the decline in dealer inventory. We think those will come close to offsetting during the second half of the year. 
Now we don't actually have an outlook for the third quarter. But if you think about the second half of the year, in a lot of ways, I think it will look similar to the first half of the year. And if you think to the first half of the year, we had a low first quarter and a pretty good second quarter. And I think, as we look at the rest of the year, the third and fourth quarter will play out similarly. We'll have probably a weak third quarter and a much better fourth quarter. Again, a lot of that is the timing of some of this E&T sales around larger projects. So we're thinking that third quarter will probably be $400 million, $500 million in sales better than the first quarter, and profit will be in the range of $0.05 to $0.10 a share better than the first quarter. And then the fourth quarter will look a lot like second quarter. Sales slightly higher, profit about the same as Q2. So that's how we think the rest of the year will shape up. 
So let's move on to the last slide that I'm going to cover today. That's Slide 10, and that's kind of key discussion points. Just a little quick recap of much of what I've talked about. On balance, there's not much change in demand from the industries that we're serving. Construction demand is relatively steady, but with continuing price pressure. We have no clear signs of recovery in mining or oil and gas, or rail for that matter. Good operational performance continues. Overall, our market position has improved. And that's been a continuing story for most of the last 5 years. Our decremental margins are pretty good and better than our target range. And that's despite a pretty negative sales mix, second quarter to second quarter. Cost reduction is substantial at $1.1 billion year-to-date, and we're thinking over $2 billion for the full year. We're on track with our restructuring actions. They have contributed to cost reduction this year, and that will contribute to more in 2017. And then finally, our balance sheet is strong. And that's very important to us because maintaining our credit rating and the dividend are very high priorities for us. 
In the second quarter, operating cash flow was $1.2 billion. Our debt-to-cap ratio for our machinery -- machining engines or Energy & Transportation business was 39%, about 21 net of about $6.8 billion of cash that we had on hand at the end of the quarter. 
So that's a wrap-up. We're now ready to move into the Q&A portion of the call.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question is coming from Ross Gilardi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question is coming from Ross Gilardi.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bank of America. Mike, some of your competitors sound maybe a little bit more sanguine on stabilization in the mining markets, at least in the aftermarket. And there just seems to be some scattered new project activity around the world. I mean, can you el
componenttext: Bank of America. Mike, some of your competitors sound maybe a little bit more sanguine on stabilization in the mining markets, at least in the aftermarket. And there just seems to be some scattered new project activity around the world. I mean, can you elaborate a little bit more on what you're seeing? Is there any chance you're losing any share right now?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say there's a -- there's some improvement in mining on the horizon around aftermarket. We are seeing a little more activity on dealer rebuilds. And we would hope that, that would translate into higher sales for us. I think one of the things t
componenttext: Yes. I would say there's a -- there's some improvement in mining on the horizon around aftermarket. We are seeing a little more activity on dealer rebuilds. And we would hope that, that would translate into higher sales for us. I think one of the things that might distinguish us a little bit from competitors is that we sell through dealers. So a lot of these projects might hit them quicker than they hit us. I mean, we're still expecting a decline in dealer inventory this year. So -- and particularly, in the second half of the year. So if we were just selling to end-user demand, sales would be a bit better than they are right now. So yes, I don't want to sound totally negative. It doesn't look to us like it's continuing to go down. And there are a few small signs like that, particularly like the rebuild activity that's a little positive. But we track share of what's being sold, and we're not seeing deterioration there. So -- it would be nice if it would improve a lot quicker. And hopefully, somewhere down the road, it will.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you just comment on the impact of lower interest rates on your pension and provide any preliminary thoughts on cash outflows into the pension next year to the extent you can?
componenttext: And can you just comment on the impact of lower interest rates on your pension and provide any preliminary thoughts on cash outflows into the pension next year to the extent you can?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll try not to get too far in front of myself. But I think, based on where we sit now, we don't see the requirement for substantial increases in contributions next year. The number, I think, is less than $0.5 billion, if memory serves me.
componenttext: Yes. I'll try not to get too far in front of myself. But I think, based on where we sit now, we don't see the requirement for substantial increases in contributions next year. The number, I think, is less than $0.5 billion, if memory serves me.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Seth Weber.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Seth Weber.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's RBC. Mike, you mentioned a couple of times in the release, there were comments about the U.S. construction equipment supply-demand imbalance. Can you comment on kind of where you think we are in the process of that smoothing out? Does equipment conti
componenttext: It's RBC. Mike, you mentioned a couple of times in the release, there were comments about the U.S. construction equipment supply-demand imbalance. Can you comment on kind of where you think we are in the process of that smoothing out? Does equipment continue to need to be moved out of the energy markets? Where are we kind of from an absorption perspective?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So kind of as we sit now, the thing that's actually been pretty good is sales that go directly to end users, rather than through a rental fleet. So the weakness right now is mostly what we've seen in and around our dealers loading rental fleets. And
componenttext: Yes. So kind of as we sit now, the thing that's actually been pretty good is sales that go directly to end users, rather than through a rental fleet. So the weakness right now is mostly what we've seen in and around our dealers loading rental fleets. And I think that's where this sort of hangover of equipment that was being used for oil and gas, a lot of it has -- resides right now. They're pretty stocked up on rental fleets. Used prices are down a bit. So that's not encouraging them to sell used equipment out of a rental fleet and replace it with new. So I think that's, right now, the reason that we're not seeing a more positive construction number in the U.S. You would hope -- I mean, time heals all things, and you would hope here, sometime over the next couple of quarters, that we'd be through that.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. If I could just ask a follow-up on the Chinese construction equipment market. The numbers there have been probably -- I think you talked a little bit more positively there last quarter. Any updated thoughts on what you're seeing in that ma
componenttext: That's helpful. If I could just ask a follow-up on the Chinese construction equipment market. The numbers there have been probably -- I think you talked a little bit more positively there last quarter. Any updated thoughts on what you're seeing in that market?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thankfully, it's not another down year there. It's sort of flattish there for the full year, up for the industry. We're doing a little better than the industry. That's kind of continuing a trend that's been going on now for a couple of years. We've g
componenttext: Yes. Thankfully, it's not another down year there. It's sort of flattish there for the full year, up for the industry. We're doing a little better than the industry. That's kind of continuing a trend that's been going on now for a couple of years. We've got great product, great dealer distribution there. I think customers are kind of coming around to the quality business model. So again, hopefully, next year can build on this. We'll have to wait and see. But at least, for this year, we're looking for, from an industry standpoint, a flattish industry.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Adam Uhlman.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Adam Uhlman.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Cleveland Research. I guess back to the second half outlook for the year. I'm a little surprised that the profits aren't going to be up more than the forecast sales increase. I guess, Mike, you'd touched on some of the factors that are behind that. C
componenttext: It's Cleveland Research. I guess back to the second half outlook for the year. I'm a little surprised that the profits aren't going to be up more than the forecast sales increase. I guess, Mike, you'd touched on some of the factors that are behind that. Could you talk to what you're seeing in material costs? And how you expect that to play out as we go into 2017 with steel prices moving higher?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's actually a great question, and I'm remiss for not having mentioned that when I talked about the second half. So we've had good cost reduction during the first half of the year for material. And our view is, we'll continue to have cost reductio
componenttext: Yes. That's actually a great question, and I'm remiss for not having mentioned that when I talked about the second half. So we've had good cost reduction during the first half of the year for material. And our view is, we'll continue to have cost reduction in the second half of the year versus 2015. But commodity prices have come up a little. So we're probably going to have less than the first half of the year. So in other words, full year, even second half versus the second half of last year positive, but the positiveness is probably peaked. And it will probably go down a little bit in the second half of the year. So that is one of the reasons, I think, that second half profitability. That, plus the inventory declines, plus the absence of the sort of $0.04 we got on the security sale in the second quarter, all kind of make it look like it doesn't hang together first half and second half of sales.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got you. And then related to the mining business, I was wondering if you could just talk about high level how you folks see the industry changing, if at all, related to the Komatsu and Joy Global merger?
componenttext: Okay. Got you. And then related to the mining business, I was wondering if you could just talk about high level how you folks see the industry changing, if at all, related to the Komatsu and Joy Global merger?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take that one. It's Doug Oberhelman here. I don't think it was any surprise that Joy was acquired, with what's happened to them and the mining industry in general, and all the mining customers, particularly coal customers, that are out there around t
componenttext: I'll take that one. It's Doug Oberhelman here. I don't think it was any surprise that Joy was acquired, with what's happened to them and the mining industry in general, and all the mining customers, particularly coal customers, that are out there around the world. Obviously, we've known Komatsu for decades. We've known Joy intimately as well the last decade or so since they emerged from bankruptcy and we entered mining in a bigger way. So neither one of these are new players. Certainly, it's a consolidation. That makes sense in the mining world. It's going to be smaller for at least a period of time. And again, we know them. They know us. And I think, going forward, we'll continue the competition just as we have in the past. And I expect us to continue winning where we win.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from David Raso.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from David Raso.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Evercore ISI. Just connecting with the carryover cost savings of '16 to '17, and then second question about the orders continuing to fall sequentially. And I can appreciate some of the seasonality in rail for second half versus first half, but just thinki
componenttext: Evercore ISI. Just connecting with the carryover cost savings of '16 to '17, and then second question about the orders continuing to fall sequentially. And I can appreciate some of the seasonality in rail for second half versus first half, but just thinking about the exit rate exiting '16 to '17, can you help us a bit where you see orders playing out from here? Have orders stabilized? Because obviously they continue to fall sequentially.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think -- no doubt about that, and it's particularly in construction. Part of that, as you mentioned, is seasonal. And I think part of that, again, is related to dealers taking inventory down during the second half of this year. Again, partly season
componenttext: Yes. I think -- no doubt about that, and it's particularly in construction. Part of that, as you mentioned, is seasonal. And I think part of that, again, is related to dealers taking inventory down during the second half of this year. Again, partly seasonal. I think partly delivery performance. We're doing a much better job of delivering on time stably to customers. So I think both of those things are contributing to lower orders. If you look at end-user demand, I'm just -- I'm talking construction here, for the second half of the year -- our sales to users that's going to be pretty steady in the second half of the year. So it's not as though we're seeing a deterioration in demand from end users. It's more dealers have lowered orders to take out some more inventory.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you exit the year with an order run rate annualized below '16, you're saying don't necessarily imply down revenues in '17. You just feel your shipping capabilities are allowing a lower order rate, so to speak -- or like a quicker turn of the backlog
componenttext: So if you exit the year with an order run rate annualized below '16, you're saying don't necessarily imply down revenues in '17. You just feel your shipping capabilities are allowing a lower order rate, so to speak -- or like a quicker turn of the backlog in the revenues?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. Yes, I think that is exactly what we're saying.
componenttext: Yes, yes. Yes, I think that is exactly what we're saying.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that's a fair assumption. The retail sales numbers are the one to watch and really drive this whole supply chain. And as long as they're steady, the chain will work itself out. And as Mike said, the second half will look different than the fi
componenttext: Yes. I think that's a fair assumption. The retail sales numbers are the one to watch and really drive this whole supply chain. And as long as they're steady, the chain will work itself out. And as Mike said, the second half will look different than the first, but that's the one that really drives us. Of course, that gets back to market share and a lot of other things as well, David.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, do you expect to see the retail sales to get flat by the end of the year so we'd feel more comfortable about that assumption for '17?
componenttext: Well, do you expect to see the retail sales to get flat by the end of the year so we'd feel more comfortable about that assumption for '17?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't know if they'll be flat-flat, but they will be -- should be closer than they are right now, yes.
componenttext: Yes. I don't know if they'll be flat-flat, but they will be -- should be closer than they are right now, yes.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the carryover cost, the Slide #7, when you say on track for over $2 billion, I'm not sure if that's an annualized number, but assuming it's a $2 billion run rate exiting the year, looking how the quarters play out or really first quarter, second
componenttext: And then the carryover cost, the Slide #7, when you say on track for over $2 billion, I'm not sure if that's an annualized number, but assuming it's a $2 billion run rate exiting the year, looking how the quarters play out or really first quarter, second quarter, second half, are you implying a carryover cost savings of $1 billion?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So that's 2016 versus 2015 costs. And we start -- a lot of that started coming out very early in 2016. Our first quarter was quite favorable. Our second quarter was even more favorable. So I think we will probably end the year with -- as you look for
componenttext: Yes. So that's 2016 versus 2015 costs. And we start -- a lot of that started coming out very early in 2016. Our first quarter was quite favorable. Our second quarter was even more favorable. So I think we will probably end the year with -- as you look forward, based on the timing of the cost reduction, a tailwind, but I don't think it would be $1 billion.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Jamie Cook.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Jamie Cook.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Crédit Suisse. A couple of clarifications. One, Mike, in the press release, and I think in your commentary, you implied Solar was flat with the first quarter, up from the beginning of the year, but you also talked about some customers pushing out orders
componenttext: Crédit Suisse. A couple of clarifications. One, Mike, in the press release, and I think in your commentary, you implied Solar was flat with the first quarter, up from the beginning of the year, but you also talked about some customers pushing out orders into '17. So I'm just wondering, is it -- is the backlog flat because of push outs or are you actually seeing order activity? And then my second question is for Doug. Doug, I mean, you've talked historically about managing to sort of targeted $3.50 trough-ish EPS. As we sit here today, given the markets don't seem to be getting better, we're already at $3.55 this year, is that off the table? Or do you think there are incremental levers that you could pull to manage profitability as we think out over the next 12 months?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start with that on the Solar piece, and then I'll turn it over to Doug. But on Solar, what we see customers pushing out a little bit is the timing of some maintenance. And that doesn't have usually as long a backlog as the new products. So it probabl
componenttext: I'll start with that on the Solar piece, and then I'll turn it over to Doug. But on Solar, what we see customers pushing out a little bit is the timing of some maintenance. And that doesn't have usually as long a backlog as the new products. So it probably impacts this year's sales a little quicker than it does backlog, just by the nature of it. I think the reason that we made a comment on Solar backlog is because everybody's concerned about it. And we're just trying to reassure everyone that they're -- what they're selling, they're replacing with new orders. That's not fallen off a cliff or off the table. And the gas business just keeps on chugging along. So I'll turn it over to Doug.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. In terms of the -- of your trough earnings question, I think your questions are reasonable ones to assume. As you say, without all the restructuring costs, we're at $3.55. And as Mike said, you take $0.08 back, we're a little bit above that even.
componenttext: Thanks. In terms of the -- of your trough earnings question, I think your questions are reasonable ones to assume. As you say, without all the restructuring costs, we're at $3.55. And as Mike said, you take $0.08 back, we're a little bit above that even. But certainly, around 40, where we are now, that's a reasonable assumption to go after. And that's where we're going to fight to try and find a bottom, if that's what we're fighting in the future.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Brad Halverson. I might just add a quick point, Doug. The trough earnings number has been stated between $2.50 and $3.50. I'd say, if you look at how -- and I would say the sales decline modeled in those scenarios would not have been as severe as
componenttext: This is Brad Halverson. I might just add a quick point, Doug. The trough earnings number has been stated between $2.50 and $3.50. I'd say, if you look at how -- and I would say the sales decline modeled in those scenarios would not have been as severe as what we've experienced in the 4-year trend. So going from above 60 down to 40, we've been absolutely trying to stay ahead of the process, to be prepared if things did not get better. If we were not staying ahead, quite frankly, there is no way we could have done $2 billion of cost reduction this year to offset some of the price pressures and the drop in volume. And we really like our mid-cycle numbers. Everybody wants to know when we're going to start recovering in that trend towards mid-cycle, but we still need to be prepared for what could happen in the short term on the downside. And so we've talked about kind of 25% to 30% decremental. I would say we're still committed to that. I would also say that we're being extremely directive in the things that we fund; things like digital, which will be up significantly this year over the last year; things like funding the businesses that we believe have the highest opportunity to improve the value of the company and it -- and our operating profit after capital charge, which we call OPACC in the medium term. So we want to fund those industries, which we think are attractive for us and where we play well. And things that are not as attractive are the places that we look first to cut. So we're still in that process, and we're still preparing to stay ahead of the game. And I would say that, if required, we would be ready.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right, Brad. And I would just come back to the incremental-decremental pull-throughs on the way up and the way down that have served us pretty well going back to '09 on the way up from $30 billion to $66 billion and then on the way down from $
componenttext: Yes, that's right, Brad. And I would just come back to the incremental-decremental pull-throughs on the way up and the way down that have served us pretty well going back to '09 on the way up from $30 billion to $66 billion and then on the way down from $66 billion to $40.25 billion this year. We've managed to stay inside of those targets all the way up and down. And I think that's probably one of the single biggest differences we've been able to accomplish from prior deep slowdowns -- in the 40% range top line -- is we've got everybody targeting those. And that's what we -- where we go after with, our cost reductions. And as Brad said, our capital allocations, and in those businesses, we really want to stay in and thrive in long term.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Jerry Revich.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Jerry Revich.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Goldman Sachs. Mike, you spoke about roughly $2 billion or so in applied dealer inventory reductions, which I think is mostly in the back half of this year. Can you just give us a flavor for the mix between construction and resource and any regional
componenttext: It's Goldman Sachs. Mike, you spoke about roughly $2 billion or so in applied dealer inventory reductions, which I think is mostly in the back half of this year. Can you just give us a flavor for the mix between construction and resource and any regional color that you can give us where you expect inventories to come down? And as we enter '17, do you think we're at normalized dealer inventory levels for the current demand environment?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of things. $2 billion is a little too high a number. It's probably more like year-over-year $1.5 billion, and it's probably split 2/3 construction, 1/3 resource in that sort of ballpark. And in terms of adequate levels, I mean, I've tried to a
componenttext: So a couple of things. $2 billion is a little too high a number. It's probably more like year-over-year $1.5 billion, and it's probably split 2/3 construction, 1/3 resource in that sort of ballpark. And in terms of adequate levels, I mean, I've tried to address this point. I think adequate levels is a little bit of a moving target around delivery performance. So again, if we were able to cut delivery performance in half from where it's at now, dealers would feel comfortable holding less inventory. If our delivery -- if -- let's say things ticked up, orders ticked up, the markets heated up, and let's say we were -- we had trouble keeping up, that would concern dealers and they would order even more. They would want to hold even more. But just the opposite is happening right now. We have excellent delivery performance. They can get pretty much what they need when their customers need it. And so that's causing them to hold or want to hold less. And the more -- the better we do with Lean, the more that will probably be the case. So I would -- I'm trying to stress a point. I don't think dealer inventories are excessive. I mean, there's a reasonable range, but I think they will come down over the second half of the year.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you're talking about the major restructuring changes. As we think about the eventual recovery, can you update us on how you're thinking about incremental margins and recovery, given the change in the manufacturing footprint?
componenttext: Okay. And you're talking about the major restructuring changes. As we think about the eventual recovery, can you update us on how you're thinking about incremental margins and recovery, given the change in the manufacturing footprint?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it should be -- and Doug has talked about this quite a bit -- on the way up we previously kind of had a 25% incremental target. But I think, while we've not quantified it, certainly our expectation is that the first chunk of what goes up, it would c
componenttext: Well, it should be -- and Doug has talked about this quite a bit -- on the way up we previously kind of had a 25% incremental target.
