But would this incremental restructuring be intended to mitigate a potential slowdown in -- from the U.K. Brexit and a potential slowing in U.S. nonres construction activity? Or would you might want to do more restructuring, if those things play out?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that's a good question. I wouldn't relate it specifically to anyone of those. I think you have to look at it in the aggregate. And Brad made actually a really important point a couple of minutes ago, and that's that we are trying to get -- we don't hav
componenttext: So that's a good question. I wouldn't relate it specifically to anyone of those. I think you have to look at it in the aggregate. And Brad made actually a really important point a couple of minutes ago, and that's that we are trying to get -- we don't have a crystal ball. We don't know what's going to happen in the marketplace, but we want to be positioned to deal with it, if it does happen. So I would say that over the course of the past quarter, we're a little more negative on the world economy. And the Brexit, the Turkey, the elections, oil price -- you name it. All of that contributes. And we're less bullish on second half sales because of that. And whatever impact that would have in the future, we're trying to get ahead of that with additional cost reductions. So I would say it's us trying to get ahead of the potential, not what we actually know and not specifically related to any one of those items.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful, Mike. And then in terms of mining profitability, the $163 million loss was a step down in the quarter compared to Q1. I mean, how are you thinking about where that goes from here? How contained can your restructuring actions keep tho
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful, Mike. And then in terms of mining profitability, the $163 million loss was a step down in the quarter compared to Q1. I mean, how are you thinking about where that goes from here? How contained can your restructuring actions keep those losses going forward?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Hopefully, this is the -- hopefully, this is the worst quarter we'll see. I think embedded within our outlook we see it getting a little bit better. Second quarter, price-wise, was deteriorated a little bit from the first quarter. And when you get to
componenttext: Yes. Hopefully, this is the -- hopefully, this is the worst quarter we'll see. I think embedded within our outlook we see it getting a little bit better. Second quarter, price-wise, was deteriorated a little bit from the first quarter. And when you get to numbers, we're talking a change, quarter-to-quarter of a couple of hundred million, not for pricing, but in total for them. Costs were a little higher because of some inventory adjustments. Just kind of normal surplus and excess inventory. And then we had a little negative inventory absorption for RI. They took out inventory in the second quarter. That hurt a little bit. They are certainly a part of the extra cost reduction that we're going after in the second half of the year. When I talked a little bit about first half, second half, we think their sales are going to be up a little bit in the second half of the year. So I think that combination of extra cost reduction and a few more sales hopefully will make this the -- make the second quarter the worst of the year.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Stephen Volkmann.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Stephen Volkmann.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Jefferies. Doug, I'm going to take you up on the -- since you mentioned infrastructure trends getting a little bit better -- how big of an opportunity is that for Cat? How much of revenue might that be? Or how should we think about sizing that going
componenttext: It's Jefferies. Doug, I'm going to take you up on the -- since you mentioned infrastructure trends getting a little bit better -- how big of an opportunity is that for Cat? How much of revenue might that be? Or how should we think about sizing that going forward?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to tell, actually. The Highway Bill -- the Federal Transportation Act that was passed last year in itself did not increase overall funding an awful lot in this country. It held it at inflation, plus a little bit, but it did get a -- did give it
componenttext: It's hard to tell, actually. The Highway Bill -- the Federal Transportation Act that was passed last year in itself did not increase overall funding an awful lot in this country. It held it at inflation, plus a little bit, but it did get a -- did give it 5 years. I think as most states have recovered from their fiscal problems the last few years, they're starting to recognize the needs for infrastructure. And we're seeing that. If there's any impact, and I've said this all year long, from that transportation act of last year, it's going to be a '17 event. We might feel it. I don't think it would move the needle a great deal, but we would certainly feel it. And It's hard to quantify until states start lining up for their matching funds. So there's quite a big effort under way to get that done as well. So we'll just have to see it play out. It's certainly going to be a positive, but I would doubt we'd see it move the needle in a big way in '17. But we'd feel it.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. And then Mike, maybe just a couple of quick modeling questions. How do we think about taxes going forward with the various changes you've had? And then what's a normal level of short-term incentive compensation, if we're thinking in
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. And then Mike, maybe just a couple of quick modeling questions. How do we think about taxes going forward with the various changes you've had? And then what's a normal level of short-term incentive compensation, if we're thinking into the out years?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two good questions, Steve. First, on taxes. All in, we're looking at a 25% tax rate this year, but that is a little lower because of all the restructuring, which has tended to be in a little higher tax jurisdictions. And so the restructuring is attracting
componenttext: Two good questions, Steve. First, on taxes. All in, we're looking at a 25% tax rate this year, but that is a little lower because of all the restructuring, which has tended to be in a little higher tax jurisdictions. And so the restructuring is attracting somewhere around, I think, low 30s -- 34%, I think. So excluding restructuring, it will vary a little bit by quarter, depending upon how much restructuring there is, but probably around 27%, excluding restructuring. And then what's normal on incentive pay, I'm going to qualify it a little bit here. It depends on how many employees we have because it scales, if you look at it in terms of dollars. But based on the number of employees we have right now, if we were to pay everyone at a 1.0 payout, which we would consider to be normal in a normal year, you're looking at something in the order of magnitude of, let's say, rough number, 8 50.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Joe O'Dea.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Joe O'Dea.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Vertical Research. First question, just on the rail side. It sounded like, from a geographic standpoint, that the softness that you would have seen year-over-year was more international. But could you just give a little bit of commentary on kind of w
componenttext: It's Vertical Research. First question, just on the rail side. It sounded like, from a geographic standpoint, that the softness that you would have seen year-over-year was more international. But could you just give a little bit of commentary on kind of what the North America trends are like for you? Incremental softness with North America rail flat year-over-year, just how kind of stable you think that is as you start to think about it more kind of downside risk, upside risk and how stable those North America trends are?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joe, I feel a little bad here. I didn't -- I've tried to prep a little on rail, but I didn't do it by region. So can't talk too much about North America specifics. Sorry. I'm just not further up to speed. What I would say is, we're looking for a bit bette
componenttext: Joe, I feel a little bad here. I didn't -- I've tried to prep a little on rail, but I didn't do it by region. So can't talk too much about North America specifics. Sorry. I'm just not further up to speed. What I would say is, we're looking for a bit better rail sales in the back half of this year. Remember, we've just introduced our new locomotive at midyear. And while sales aren't huge for that right now, kind of given the state of the overall industry, we certainly are going to sell some. So that's part of the increase in the back half of the year.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on resources, it seemed like in the first quarter, one of the challenges was aftermarket came in a little lighter than we would've expected to start off the year, with the expectation that moving deeper into '16, that would improve. From a
componenttext: Okay. And then on resources, it seemed like in the first quarter, one of the challenges was aftermarket came in a little lighter than we would've expected to start off the year, with the expectation that moving deeper into '16, that would improve. From a margin standpoint, it didn't look like there was a mix benefit in the second quarter. But could you just talk about kind of sequential trends? What you're hearing from dealers? The scheduled rebuilds? It sounds like that's a little bit better. Did you see some improvement in aftermarket from first quarter to second quarter?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're hearing the dealers are booking a little -- a bit more. In fact, I verified that with our mining group last night. They are seeing -- dealers are seeing an uptick of bookings around rebuild. Haven't really hit our parts business quite get. But
componenttext:
Well, we're hearing the dealers are booking a little -- a bit more. In fact, I verified that with our mining group last night. They are seeing -- dealers are seeing an uptick of bookings around rebuild. Haven't really hit our parts business quite get. But hopefully, it will. And your synopsis of no big upturn in parts sales around mining is actually correct, at least so far. 
All right. Well, I think we're at the top of the hour here. Actually, a minute or so over. So we'll conclude the call. Thank you very much.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. This does conclude today's conference call. You may disconnect your phone lines at this time, and have a wonderful day. Thank you for your participation.
componenttext: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. This does conclude today's conference call. You may disconnect your phone lines at this time, and have a wonderful day. Thank you for your participation.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Caterpillar Third Quarter 2016 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Mike DeWalt. Sir, the floor is yours.
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Caterpillar Third Quarter 2016 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Mike DeWalt. Sir, the floor is yours.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Paul, and good morning, everyone on the call. I'm Mike DeWalt, Caterpillar's Vice President of Financial Services. On the call with me this morning, we have Doug Oberhelman, our Chairman and CEO. We have Jim Umpleby, who will be tak
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Paul, and good morning, everyone on the call. I'm Mike DeWalt, Caterpillar's Vice President of Financial Services. 
On the call with me this morning, we have Doug Oberhelman, our Chairman and CEO. We have Jim Umpleby, who will be taking over the reins from Doug as CEO come January; and Brad Halverson, our Group President and CFO.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good morning, everybody. It's Doug Oberhelman here. And I just want to make a few opening comments, and I'll get back to -- we'll get back to Mike in [ph] a normal conference call stuff. I want to talk a little bit about the succession planning pro
componenttext:
Yes. Good morning, everybody. It's Doug Oberhelman here. And I just want to make a few opening comments, and I'll get back to -- we'll get back to Mike in [ph] a normal conference call stuff. 
I want to talk a little bit about the succession planning process that the board used, just make a few comments on that. We have a -- and [ph] we've talked about this before in analyst conferences and so on, but we have a very robust succession planning process that goes all the way down to almost the first levels of management. We review and spend a lot of time on that every year. And every year, at least once, usually in October, we go through that with the board for, let's say, [ph] the top 300 -- top 350 people and talk about succession, the future, some names. And then, during the year, we try to introduce the board to a lot of those names and individuals, as we have been doing. 
I certainly have been active in that. I was very adamant that I wanted, when my time was up, and I'll be 64 in February. When I retire at the end of March, I will be 64 years old, with just a few months to go before I'm 65. Pretty much right on the process. There's no drama here, contrary to a lot of the stuff that's going around. But I wanted to -- I was adamant with the board that I wanted a very good, sound process to use, that they were happy with it, our executive office team was happy with it at the end. And both the -- all the executive officers then would go right on through performance and not miss a beat. I think we've achieved that. I picked the timing. I've been very much supportive of Jim. I'm very much supportive of the full executive office. And as we announced a week ago yesterday, I will be CEO until the end of December, and I will be Executive Chairman until the end of March. But we did make a change in governance with a split chair and CEO role. I think most of you know we've had a shareholder proposal on that for several years in a row, and we have a couple of large shareholders that are fundamentally for that. They pushed that at transition times, and obviously, this was a time the board considered that because we were in transition. 
Dave Calhoun will be the Executive Chairman come April 1. I would tell you that I've had a wonderful relationship and extensive and also frequent with the current residing director, Ed Rust, and we talked frequently, before, during and after the -- every single board meeting, and have for years, since I've been on the job. David's role will not be anything different to [ph] Jim. Jim will run the company, and David will coordinate the board as Executive Chair. Just a change in governance. Both work very well. I've had great luck with the presiding director situation, and I'm sure Jim and Dave will have great luck with the split chair, CEO role as well. Again, no drama. Just a different way of doing things, and I think we'll carry on and not even miss a beat. 
So with that, little preamble, I will tell you I'm excited to move into the next phase. I'm very excited for Jim and the executive team that we have here. I feel the company's positioned. We've been through an awful rough period the last 4 years, as all of you have known and endured, but I do think we're set up for the future. So Mike, if you'd take over.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, Jim.
componenttext: Actually, Jim.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Sorry, Jim. I meant to introduce Jim Umpleby officially. And if -- Jim, so if you have a couple of comments, that would be great. Thank you, and sorry.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug, and hello again to everyone on the line. It's an honor and privilege to be selected as the next CEO of Caterpillar. I have worked with Doug for many years. I have great respect for him, and I'm proud to be part of his team that has kept Cate
componenttext: Thanks, Doug, and hello again to everyone on the line. It's an honor and privilege to be selected as the next CEO of Caterpillar. I have worked with Doug for many years. I have great respect for him, and I'm proud to be part of his team that has kept Caterpillar strong throughout some of the most difficult market conditions that we've faced. Like other incoming CEOs, I'll pull together a team of leaders that will refresh our enterprise strategy in the coming months. Again, it's an honor to have been chosen to lead this great company. Thank you. Mike, back to you.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: All righty. Let's get on to the outlook. Today, we'll be walking through a short slide deck, similar to what we've done for the past few quarters, and then we'll move on to the Q&A. Now would be a great time. If you don't have that slide deck in front of
componenttext:
All righty. Let's get on to the outlook. Today, we'll be walking through a short slide deck, similar to what we've done for the past few quarters, and then we'll move on to the Q&A. Now would be a great time. If you don't have that slide deck in front of you, you can pick it up on our caterpillar.com website with -- where the conference call webcast link was. 
Just as a reminder, this call is copyrighted by Caterpillar Inc., and any use, recording or transmission of any portion of the call without the consent of Caterpillar is strictly prohibited. If you'd like a copy of today's call transcript, we will be posting at the Investors section of that same caterpillar.com website, and it'll be in a section labeled Results Webcast. 
So if you go to Page 2 on this morning's slide deck, you'll see our forward-looking statements, and I am quite certain that, this morning, we're going to be discussing quite a bit of forward-looking information, and that always involves risks and uncertainties and assumptions that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking information. 
In addition to Page 2 of the slide deck, [ph] a discussion of some of those factors that, either individually or in aggregate, could make results differ can be found in our cautionary statements under Item 1A, which is Risk Factors, from our Form 10-K filed with the SEC earlier this year and in the forward-looking statements language in today's release. 
Now in addition, a reconciliation of non-GAAP measures that are used in both our financial release and this presentation can be found in both the financial release and the last page of the slide deck. 
One more thing, actually, before we get started on the slide deck. And I know that with Doug's announced retirement and with Jim replacing him, I suspect you have a lot of questions for Jim about his long-term strategy. But I would say, since Jim found out he's going to be CEO just about 10 days ago, now is probably not the best time for those kind of questions. So what we're going to ask is, today, we're going to try and keep the call here to our third quarter results, the outlook for the fourth quarter and kind of our preliminary view of sales for next year. 
So with that, let's start on the slide deck, and if you could flip to Page 4. And on Page 4, that's a high-level summary of what happened in the third quarter to sales and profit -- sales and revenues and profit. So we were down $1.8 billion in the quarter, kind of continued on the same trajectory we've been most of the year. Profit per share dropped from $0.94 per share last year in the third quarter to $0.48 this quarter. Quite a bit of that was from more restructuring costs. Certainly, in the quarter, we had asset impairments -- additional asset impairments related to our Resource Industries business, and restructuring costs were $226 million higher than a year ago. If you exclude the restructuring costs, profit per share was down $0.20, which, I think, is pretty good performance on a $1.8 billion drop in sales. And that'll be a theme, I think, across the next few slides that we'll talk about. Cost reduction was very good. 
So if we go to the next page, it'll kind of walk us through the change in sales in a little bit more detail. So the most significant decline was in Energy & Transportation. We were down a little over $800 million. And transportation -- and in fact, this is, I think, the first time all year we've said that oil and gas was not the most significant reason. But this quarter, it was transportation, followed by power gen, oil and gas and industrial engines. 
Resource Industries was down $465 million. That's about -- that's a little over 25%, and it's been kind of down about in that range every quarter this year. So not a big change. And it's actually a split between mining products and large construction. We don't talk much about construction in Resource Industries, but we have large products like articulated trucks, some of the smaller off-highway trucks, some of the large bulldozers, some of the large wheel loaders are used in construction. And a pretty good decline this quarter in Resource Industries was from construction equipment, and we're seeing that -- quite a bit of that in North America. 
For the Construction Industries segment, we were down $521 million. And again, about 2/3 of that was volume, North America was the most significant region; and about 1/3 of that was price. So the total decline then is $1.8 billion. 
So let's maybe flip to the next slide, Page 6, talk a little bit about profit. And this is our normal waterfall chart. So on the left, the black bar is the third quarter operating profit from a year ago. And then we're isolating what caused changes. So you can see, without a doubt, that $1.8 billion decline in sales and revenues drove substantial impact on profit from lower volume. 
Price realization has remained pretty decent-sized negative, about the same as versus a year ago and [ph] last quarter. It was $213 million this quarter. The next 2 bars are the positives. Variable manufacturing costs, that's cost absorption, that's material cost, that's variable labor and overhead in our factories. And that's been positive for all year. Period costs, we've done a lot of work to take structural costs out of the company, and we've actually performed very well on this all year long. 
And then a couple of bars to the right is the restructuring cost. If you look at the decline in operating profit, about half of the decline was from the restructuring cost. So excluding restructuring costs, on the prior page, you saw we were down $0.20. It's a little over $200 million in operating profit. And if you look at that price realization bucket, had we not been in such a difficult pricing environment this quarter, we would have had enough variable and period cost reduction to essentially offset the impact of $1.8 billion in lower sales. 
Now I'm going to ask you to do something I normally wouldn't do at this time. Let's just back up, given that good cost performance. Let's back up to the previous page one more time. So when we look at Energy & Transportation, our sales were down $818 million, but the profit on that level of sales decline was only off $111 million. I think that indicates great cost performance. 
Construction Industries, $521 million decline in sales and revenues in -- and $165 million of that was price realization. Despite that, their profit was only down $28 million. 
Resource Industries, mining and large construction down $465 million in sales, but their profit was down only $35 million. So I think that -- when you look at the change in profit in the context with the change in sales, it just reinforces the point that I made a minute ago, that cost reduction has been very good so far this year. 
So if we move on to Page 7 and look at where we've been on cost reduction this year. You can see, through the first 9 months of the year, we're favorable about $1.8 billion. And that breaks down into 3 major categories. The first is restructuring efforts. We've been on that path for a few years. We announced a fairly big series of restructuring actions last September. And with all those actions, we've reduced square footage, capacity and people. Material cost has been favorable this year. And I know it's tempting to always think about that as just commodity-based, but the fact of the matter is, we've gotten more cost reduction from design- and sourcing-related changes than we have from commodity prices. And then there's everything else, and that includes short-term incentive pay. A little over $300 million of the $1.8 billion is from lower incentive pay this year, at least for [ph] our expectations. And -- so even without that, we're $1.5 billion of lower costs this year. 
So that's a little bit about the third quarter. Again, tough sales environment, very good progress on cost reduction across the board. 
So let's look at the outlook. We did lower the 2016 outlook. Previously, we were thinking $40 billion to $40.5 billion for the year and $2.75 profit per share, $3.55 without restructuring costs. Now we've lowered that. We think sales and revenues are going to be about $39 billion this year and profit will be $2.35 a share or $3.25 excluding restructuring costs. 
Now sales came down. So at the midpoint of the outlook, that's about $1.25 billion decline in sales, and that came out across -- relatively evenly across Construction Industries, Resource Industries and Energy & Transportation. Now the decline for construction is [ph] particularly in North America, and the weakness in North American construction is impacted, both our Construction Industries segment and, to some degree, Resource Industries for large equipment. So I think -- that's one of the bigger reasons for the decline in the outlook. 
In Energy & Transportation, we also took down rail. We had some business that we thought was going to ship in the second half, and it's been pushed out to later years. And we've also had some decline in oil and gas, and that's mostly from service and overhaul work related to Solar. You always have a lot of questions about Solar. We were thinking Solar was going to be down about 10% this year. It looks like, based on where we're at now, it'll be closer to 15%, and most of that change is related to service and overhaul work, not new turbine sales. 
Power generation has also been down. It's been particularly weak in oil-producing regions. From a profit standpoint, our restructuring costs are about $100 million higher than we expect for the year, and most of that was from the additional asset write-offs that we had in Resource Industries in the third quarter. 
So we don't normally give quarterly guidance, but when we get to this point in the year, we have 3 quarters of actual, and we have a full year forecast. So it's pretty easy to figure out what we're thinking about the fourth quarter. And based on this outlook, it implies about $10 billion of sales and revenues, $0.47 a share profit and $0.67 excluding restructuring. 
If we move to the next page, Page 9, I'll kind of walk you through why, on higher sales, we think profit in the fourth quarter is going to be a bit lower. 
So if you look at the third quarter and the implied fourth quarter outlook, we have sales and revenues up about $800 million. Most all of that is in Energy & Transportation. We always have some seasonality in our fourth quarter sales, so this is probably not a surprise to you. We also have more locomotive shipments in the fourth quarter, particularly Tier 4 locomotives, and we have some large turnkey power generation projects in the fourth quarter. Profit on that higher sales, excluding the restructuring costs, we think, will be about $0.18 lower. And of course, one positive is higher volume. We do have a substantial offset of the higher volume on sales mix. And this is also not, I don't think, very unusual. Over the last couple of years, that's been the case for us. And we've had lower margins in the fourth quarter, and they've tended to rebound then in the first quarter. And we think that's likely the case here as well. 
Cost absorption, one of the things that also happens commonly with us is we -- and it's partly related to the higher sales, we have, usually, a pretty good-sized inventory reduction in the fourth quarter. We're expecting that again this year. And that, we think, will result in negative cost absorption. 
We had -- in the third quarter, because we lowered the outlook, we had a favorable kind of year-to-date adjustment in the third quarter for incentive compensation. We certainly don't expect that to repeat in the fourth quarter. So relative -- third to fourth is going to be negative for that. 
And then another item that we talk about quite a bit in the fourth quarter is a bit of seasonally higher costs at year-end, and we don't have any reason to believe this year will be any different than prior years. So we'd probably -- we expect a little bit of a cost increase in the fourth quarter. 
So that's a little bit about the fourth quarter. Now let's talk about 2017, and that's Page 10. Now we usually provide a preliminary view of next year in our third quarter release, and so we're doing that again this year. It's always difficult at this time of the year to predict that. It's -- the quarter doesn't even start for -- the year doesn't even start for a couple more months. But at this point in time, on balance, we're not expecting 2017 to be significantly different than '16. It doesn't mean that it couldn't be different. That just means, at this point in time, it's a little hard to predict. We have -- we try to give you some insight into our thinking here by providing a list of the positives and a list of the things that we're concerned about. And on the very first bullet, you'll see they're kind of the same thing, and that's commodity prices. So on the plus side, commodity prices have improved from earlier this year, and with -- like oil, for example, it seemed to stabilize somewhere around $50. And certainly, compared with where we were, that's good. That's a positive signal. On the concern side of that, we don't think commodity prices are still quite good enough to drive substantial sales increases next year. We would like to see commodity prices rise more next year. If that happens, that, we think, logically, would be upside for the second half of next year. If that doesn't happen, probably not upside then. On the positive side, construction in China, that's been generally positive this year. Both our market position -- we're doing a bit better than most of our competitors, and the market there is improved. And that's been good for us. If you look at today's release, for example, the one up sales increase that we have in our release is in construction in Asia. If memory serves me, we were up about 9% there. And we think as long as there's continued support for growth in China that next year can be up as well. Construction sales in some other developing countries, particularly in places like Brazil, where it's just been very, very challenging situation. CIS is in that category, too. Been a very, very challenging year for both Brazil because of deep recession. Russia, and actually, much of the Middle East as well because of low commodity prices. We kind of think that sales in many of these countries may have bottomed, and there's every opportunity to think that, in places like that, we could have some upside next year. 
Been around mining, and this is a bit related to the commodity comments earlier. It looks to us like the CapEx forecasts are flattening out, and sentiment amongst customers and dealers has been a little bit better. And that's good. On the concern side, in addition to commodity prices, North American construction over the last -- in the third quarter and in the fourth quarter is weaker than we would have thought a few months ago. And if that continues, that would be concerning next year as well. Hopefully, with all the election noise behind us, and particularly if we get some investment in U.S. infrastructure, that could help. But right now, I would think, on balance, it looks pretty tough. 
Economic growth in Europe, it's been kind of okay, but we're still concerned about Brexit. And as that draws nearer, the concerns that we have are -- does it impact economic growth and business confidence and investment? 
I think another fallout from the lower oil prices has been power gen, particularly in the oil-producing regions. It's very weak now, and we don't see anything in the short term that's going to change that around. 
And also kind of related to commodities in a way, Marine, particularly for offshore service vessels, we're concerned about. And rail remains very weak industry, particularly in North America. And industrial engine sales to ag customers, that's lose engine sales that we sell to ag customers and particularly ag and some power gen packagers remain pretty weak. 
I know with Solar it's always a topic of discussion. So I thought I would kind of give you the -- our current view of Solar as well. So right now, we've had a pretty stable backlog. Based on where it's at right now, it would give us expectations that Solar would be about flat next year with this year. I know you're concerned about how this will play out by segment, and I would tell you that it's not a lot. I mean, when we say not significantly different than '17, by and large, that's probably pretty similar across most of the segments. I would say probably slightly more negative with Energy & Transportation than, say, Resource Industries, which is at such a low bottom. I mean, new equipment sales in the big mining product is down 80% to 90% since 2012, not as much room there for downside. 
So with that, we'll just wrap up with a few discussion points on Page 11. Not much change over the past quarter in the industries we serve, with the exception of North American construction, which has -- which is disappointing. We've had great operational performance, and that's not just cost reduction. Our market position vis-à-vis our competitors was better this quarter than a year ago for raw machines and continues to improve in China. Our decrementals in every single segment were very good year-over-year. Cost reduction -- and that's driven by cost reduction, which is quite substantial. We're pretty well on track with restructuring. Most of the things that are of any magnitude that we were considering a year ago in September, with that announcement have been made public. Balance sheet remains strong. Our debt to -- our ME&T debt to cap is 37% at the end of the quarter. And we had a cash balance of over $6 billion, and we're still thinking that this year will be positive free cash flow. 
So with that, I think we're ready to turn it over for questions.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And the first question is coming from Andrew Casey.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the first question is coming from Andrew Casey.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wells Fargo Securities. On 2017, can you review some of the puts and takes we should consider when looking at the year, in addition to the revenue outlook you provided today? And then also, given the market, outlook is pretty flat. Are you considering any
componenttext: Wells Fargo Securities. On 2017, can you review some of the puts and takes we should consider when looking at the year, in addition to the revenue outlook you provided today? And then also, given the market, outlook is pretty flat. Are you considering any incremental cost-removal actions?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as we said on sales, I'll start with that. On balance, we're not seeing a significant difference. But we said this in the release, I think we're much more cautious about the first half of the year, and we're -- the flattish for the year relies on
componenttext: Yes. So as we said on sales, I'll start with that. On balance, we're not seeing a significant difference. But we said this in the release, I think we're much more cautious about the first half of the year, and we're -- the flattish for the year relies on a bit of improvement in the second half of the year. So I think, to your point on costs, I would suspect, as we wrap this up, we will be planning and trying to set a cost structure for something that's probably a little bit more conservative than what we're thinking sales for the year can be. So it will remain a very big focus on cost and cost reduction. Won't get into too many of the details yet. As you know, we're kind of in the middle of our planning process for next year right now. But I think some big things that you could certainly expect, one, we'll have a big headwind. I don't know how much yet, but we'll likely have a pretty sizable headwind on incentive compensation. This year, we're pretty -- we're off of our outlook in most areas, off of our plan. So we'll have less-than-expected short-term incentive comps this year for all of our employees. And something more normal going into next year could be a headwind of $500 million, $600 million, depending upon where the executive team and the board sets the target. So that would be a headwind. On the positive side, we've done very well on costs. We've taken out more costs as we've gone along this year. So we'll have some benefits from carryover impact of that. So that should be a tailwind. We've done very well on material costs. And again, much of the commodity benefit and material costs, with the rise in commodity prices, has come out. But even without commodity changes, we've done very well on sourcing and design with material cost. So I think we would see that as a tailwind for next year. So we're still working on all the other items in the plan. And when we get to January, we'll definitely do a more complete review of sales and the profit drivers.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could follow up on the guidance for this year, the $3.25. I think, in the past, $3.55 included some benefit from change in pension OPEB policies. Is that still in the $3.25? And how should we view that in 2017?
componenttext: Okay. And if I could follow up on the guidance for this year, the $3.25. I think, in the past, $3.55 included some benefit from change in pension OPEB policies. Is that still in the $3.25? And how should we view that in 2017?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes -- what -- when -- essentially, the change that we made had the impact of taking out prior year amortization of gains and losses related to the assets and liabilities in the pension plan and more -- and better reflects what the -- I don't know, I gues
componenttext: Yes -- what -- when -- essentially, the change that we made had the impact of taking out prior year amortization of gains and losses related to the assets and liabilities in the pension plan and more -- and better reflects what the -- I don't know, I guess, I'll call it actual ongoing pension costs. So it's not that there's a big benefit. I think it's just stated more around what the actual expense is for the year. And we're -- we made that accounting change effective the beginning of this year. The prior -- the couple of prior years were restated, and we're going to maintain that -- certainly that accounting treatment.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Sameer Rathod.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Sameer Rathod.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Macquarie. My question is on excess capacity. It seems like rationalization, normal rationalization, isn't really happening, given the excessive liquidity provided by central banks. Does captive deflationary pressures or pricing pressure will continue in
componenttext: Macquarie. My question is on excess capacity. It seems like rationalization, normal rationalization, isn't really happening, given the excessive liquidity provided by central banks. Does captive deflationary pressures or pricing pressure will continue in this environment? Or does it somehow naturally abate? Or do you think M&A is the only channel for supply rationalization?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sameer, I've heard all the words you said, but I'm not -- is it a question on pricing or what we do?
componenttext: Sameer, I've heard all the words you said, but I'm not -- is it a question on pricing or what we do?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Caterpillar has indicated excess capacity being a problem for price realization. My point is, if there's excess liquidity, Corporation, so to speak, not going out of business, does the price realization continue to deteriorate?
componenttext: Caterpillar has indicated excess capacity being a problem for price realization. My point is, if there's excess liquidity, Corporation, so to speak, not going out of business, does the price realization continue to deteriorate?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. I get it. Okay. So we -- our pricing over the last couple of quarters, it's certainly unfavorable to a year ago, but it's stabilized from what we see going forward over the next quarter anyway. In fact, we had a Q&A in the release on this. We
componenttext: Okay, good. I get it. Okay. So we -- our pricing over the last couple of quarters, it's certainly unfavorable to a year ago, but it's stabilized from what we see going forward over the next quarter anyway. In fact, we had a Q&A in the release on this. We don't see the pricing environment actually getting worse. That doesn't mean the pricing environment -- saying it's not getting worse doesn't mean that it's good. Kind of maintaining it at this level is actually a pretty significant negative to our results. I mean, it was $200 million drag on the quarter, but we don't, at this point, see it getting worse from here. It's a pretty tough overall. But barring some large event in the world economy, that we're certainly not expecting, I think we would see, from this point, at not very attractive levels, stable pricing.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Jamie Cook.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Jamie Cook.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Crédit Suisse. I guess, Mike, my first question -- I appreciate the color on the fourth quarter revenues as well as the EPS and why the EPS is lighter. But can you just give me a little more color? Have you changed your assumptions in terms of where deal
componenttext: Crédit Suisse. I guess, Mike, my first question -- I appreciate the color on the fourth quarter revenues as well as the EPS and why the EPS is lighter. But can you just give me a little more color? Have you changed your assumptions in terms of where dealer inventory should be at the end of the year and Cat's inventories relative your previous guide? Because I think what everyone is trying to get a better understanding in -- of it as we approach 2017, what's your confidence level that we should start to produce in line with retail demand, given where we are today? So I guess that's my first question. And then also, you mentioned a couple of times about your 2017 revenue assumption the first half is weaker versus the second half, back to where -- how we'll be producing relative to in line with retail demand. It's a second half improvement. You're assuming the markets get better? Or is there some change in what would be normal seasonality in terms of production for Caterpillar?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I -- predicting dealer inventory precisely is always difficult, but I think, based on where we've been year-to-date and what's likely, I think, in the fourth quarter, and this will be a plus or minus, probably a couple of hundred million dollars, but
componenttext: Yes. I -- predicting dealer inventory precisely is always difficult, but I think, based on where we've been year-to-date and what's likely, I think, in the fourth quarter, and this will be a plus or minus, probably a couple of hundred million dollars, but probably something around -- dealer inventory, in its totality, around $1.5 billion decline this year with probably somewhere close to half of that coming out in the fourth quarter of this year. So we are not currently producing to end-market demand. This year, let's say, order of magnitude, $1.5 billion lower. Now when you start talking about next year. I'll tell you what makes it really difficult to predict. It depends a lot how we'll end the year, depends a lot on how the second half of the year turns out and what expectations for 2018 are. So for example, if things start improving in the middle of next year and there's confidence that 2018 is going to be a better year, part of dealer inventory is thinking about what's going to be needed for the future, not what was needed in the past. So that would tend to help dealer inventory. If 2018 looks bad, if there's some sort of a world event and dealers are more pessimistic, there would likely be some additional dealer inventory reduction. I think it -- I think we'll probably be in a better position to talk about that maybe more in January, but I would say, in our current estimates, we do continue to have some level of dealer inventory reduction in for next year. I guess, at this point, let's just call it a placeholder, but probably not as much as this year.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in a flat environment, we'll still be underproducing retail demand next year?
componenttext: So in a flat environment, we'll still be underproducing retail demand next year?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say so. Yes.
componenttext: I would say so. Yes.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And is there any way to give color? I mean, I know it's not the $1.5 billion would be considerably less than that. Can you talk about which markets they would be targeting? And I guess the second question on that is, why not just get it out of the w
componenttext: Okay. And is there any way to give color? I mean, I know it's not the $1.5 billion would be considerably less than that. Can you talk about which markets they would be targeting? And I guess the second question on that is, why not just get it out of the way, Mike, this year versus have this big issue in 2017?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't control dealer inventory. Dealers are independent. What they decide, it's not up to us. It's up to dealers and what their confidence level is. They're the ones selling to end customers. So it's not something that we can force to be behind u
componenttext: Well, we don't control dealer inventory. Dealers are independent. What they decide, it's not up to us. It's up to dealers and what their confidence level is. They're the ones selling to end customers. So it's not something that we can force to be behind us. And we just don't -- it's also very seasonal. Dealers will want to likely build some inventory in the first quarter for the second quarter selling season. So it's not as simple as you might think.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And in buckets and where it is? Is it just mining and construction?

componenttext: Well, it's been mining, construction and some E&T this year. It's been across all 3. I think construction for the year will probably be a bit more than the other 2. Definitely [indiscernible]

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: And the next question is coming from Ross Gilardi.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bank of America. Mike, I've tried this one for a few years in a row. I'm going to try it again same time of year. Cat, I believe, has got $3.6 billion in goodwill still residing in its mining segment. And as you've mentioned in your formal remarks, as we
componenttext: Bank of America. Mike, I've tried this one for a few years in a row. I'm going to try it again same time of year. Cat, I believe, has got $3.6 billion in goodwill still residing in its mining segment. And as you've mentioned in your formal remarks, as we know, new equipment sales are down 80% to 90% since you bought [indiscernible] your annual impairment testing, I think, is coming in the fourth quarter. I'm not asking if you would write it -- if you're going to write it off because obviously that's an auditor decision, but if you show -- if you did write-off the $3.6 billion in goodwill, would it potentially jeopardize either the dividend due to stipulations on shareholders' equity in your borrowing agreements or negatively impact your credit rating?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Those are the questions, so I'm -- I'll try to talk about it rather than giving a direct answer because our credit rating is up to the rating agencies. I -- but first off, if we knew what the result of the fourth quarter goodwill testing would be, we book
componenttext: Those are the questions, so I'm -- I'll try to talk about it rather than giving a direct answer because our credit rating is up to the rating agencies. I -- but first off, if we knew what the result of the fourth quarter goodwill testing would be, we book it. We don't. We go through a defined process every year. We're going through that now, and we're pretty straight up. If there's an impairment, we'll book it. If there's not, we won't. In terms of the effect on the company, that is -- would entirely be a noncash item. It would affect equity, of course, but it's a non -- totally noncash transaction. I can't imagine that would impact the dividend.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: But in terms of not having it written off, it -- up until now, I mean, how could Cat say that the assumptions around what it's worth on a discounted cash flow haven't changed materially since the time you bought it and put that goodwill on your balance sh
componenttext: But in terms of not having it written off, it -- up until now, I mean, how could Cat say that the assumptions around what it's worth on a discounted cash flow haven't changed materially since the time you bought it and put that goodwill on your balance sheet to begin with?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I -- that's a longer discussion. First, there is no Bucyrus. Bucyrus does not exist, and the goodwill is not in one measurement, not in one measurement bucket. We measure goodwill. We do the work based on which of our business it's in and that goodw
componenttext: Well, I -- that's a longer discussion. First, there is no Bucyrus. Bucyrus does not exist, and the goodwill is not in one measurement, not in one measurement bucket. We measure goodwill. We do the work based on which of our business it's in and that goodwill is spread across more than one business. And also remember that some of the goodwill was -- or the intangibles and goodwill changed after we acquired Bucyrus and sold a portion of it to dealers. So some of it left already. We -- in our K last year, we provided more color on our goodwill. And the segment that has more of the -- or that had the closest a year ago to triggering an impairment, I think, if memory serves me, it was about 15% off. That segment houses about $1.2 billion of the goodwill. So it's -- we don't have a Bucyrus. Everybody wants to think we do. But it's been integrated in across a couple of different businesses within the company. And so the measurement is not just Bucyrus because it doesn't exist. It's the -- it's each of those businesses that we have. That's how it's done. So -- I don't know if we have an impairment or not. I'm not saying we will, not saying we won't. I -- we just have to go through the process and we'll know in the fourth quarter. If we do, we'll book it. If we don't, we won't.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from David Raso.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from David Raso.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Evercore ISI. I'm just trying to think about the cadence and confidence in the 2017 outlook. When I look at the orders, the orders are down about 10% year-over-year, and they have to grow about 5% sequentially, just so the fourth quarter orders are still
componenttext: Evercore ISI. I'm just trying to think about the cadence and confidence in the 2017 outlook. When I look at the orders, the orders are down about 10% year-over-year, and they have to grow about 5% sequentially, just so the fourth quarter orders are still down just 10%. Can you give us some color what you're seeing currently on your order trends and how to think about those numbers would that cadence for '17 sales? Because again, when these orders up [ph] 5% sequentially to still be down 10% year-over-year starting next year?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dave. I think I'd have to write all of that down on a piece of paper to follow what you're saying, but our backlog from second to third quarter didn't change much. I think, in construction, the backlog is in most of the products outside of maybe Chin
componenttext: Yes, Dave. I think I'd have to write all of that down on a piece of paper to follow what you're saying, but our backlog from second to third quarter didn't change much. I think, in construction, the backlog is in most of the products outside of maybe China is fairly weak. I think we don't normally have a long backlog for businesses like construction. That product ships in the range of 8 to 15 weeks, so you don't have a long backlog. Dealers are -- I've said a minute ago, dealers are planning to cut inventory in the fourth quarter. So I think, naturally, they're ordering less. We would certainly expect a pickup in orders in the first quarter as they want to build some inventory for the second quarter selling season. In the case of Solar, backlog is reasonable. And based on everything we know about history, should be reasonably in line with the flat year next year. So how confident are we in next year's sort of preliminary view? I think we are confident that the first half will definitely be challenged. And I guess if you want to read into that down, I think that's probably a reasonable way to think of it. How confident are we that the back half of the year will improve? I think that will depend largely on what happens to the U.S. economy, U.S. construction and whether or not this trend of maybe part sales firming in construction happens and whether or not we start to see orders from mining companies, which we haven't seen much of so far. We're encouraged by the commodity prices, the sentiment, the discussion on CapEx, but probably to the point that you're making, that has not turned into orders of any magnitude yet. So our confidence in the year does rely on a pickup in orders going forward. [indiscernible]

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, [indiscernible] a lot of mining orders to turn it into a big positive year-over-year. So I mean, 6 months, 9 months as far enough out, I appreciate -- I mean, it could be up in the second half nicely. But I'm just trying to think what we have visi
componenttext: I mean, [indiscernible] a lot of mining orders to turn it into a big positive year-over-year. So I mean, 6 months, 9 months as far enough out, I appreciate -- I mean, it could be up in the second half nicely. But I'm just trying to think what we have visibility on in that kind of 3, 6 months, kind of view that the orders sequentially -- and I'm -- again, I'm just giving you the numbers, if orders are flat sequentially, we're still down 14% year-over-year going into '17. And I'm just trying to get a feel from you. Are you saying your orders sequentially right now feel flattish? Up or down? Just for some perspective.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't recall disclosing orders. So I'd have to look at your math. Have to talk about it off-line. That's -- orders aren't something that we disclose. And when you look at orders, you definitely have to consider how much is aftermarket, how much is
componenttext: Yes. I don't recall disclosing orders. So I'd have to look at your math. Have to talk about it off-line. That's -- orders aren't something that we disclose. And when you look at orders, you definitely have to consider how much is aftermarket, how much is not aftermarket. I mean, the length of the order board for parts is about 2 days. The length of the order board for rail can be 2 years. So it just depends upon the product in terms of what it means for the short term.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one last follow-up. The R&D, you didn't mention in the year-over-year puts and takes. I would have thought the R&D, which is already running down 14% for the third quarter, it was down 11% in the second quarter, would be an area of cost savings for ne
componenttext: And one last follow-up. The R&D, you didn't mention in the year-over-year puts and takes. I would have thought the R&D, which is already running down 14% for the third quarter, it was down 11% in the second quarter, would be an area of cost savings for next year. Is there a reason you didn't highlight it?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And the reason I didn't highlight it is because we've not gone through -- we're not done with the plan for next year. And one of the things that we have to address between now and the time we do talk to you about profit is in places where we have dis
componenttext: Yes. And the reason I didn't highlight it is because we've not gone through -- we're not done with the plan for next year. And one of the things that we have to address between now and the time we do talk to you about profit is in places where we have discretion on timing of spending, what we're going to prioritize and what we're going to do. We're not through that yet in the planning process. That will come over the next probably 6 weeks or so.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: But it's fair to say, it should be positive? I mean, it should be down next year is a fair directional assumption?
componenttext: But it's fair to say, it should be positive? I mean, it should be down next year is a fair directional assumption?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll tell you what, I'm going to avoid saying that because we've not been through that sort of resource allocation discussion yet within the company. I mean, I can understand how you would think that, and that may well be the case, but before I get us pos
componenttext: I'll tell you what, I'm going to avoid saying that because we've not been through that sort of resource allocation discussion yet within the company. I mean, I can understand how you would think that, and that may well be the case, but before I get us positioned on that, I think we need to get to our planning process.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: It's Barclays. Congratulations to Doug and Jim. Doug, we've written that -- the work that Cat has done of your 10-year on competitive position production systems, market share, it's going to pay off for years and decades to come. So congratulations.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you, Rob. Appreciate that.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is a little bit level of a low-level question. SG&A was really low in the quarter, really good, really good cost control. And obviously, the incentive comp was part of that. But even with the incentive comp up like $100 million, again it seems have b
componenttext: This is a little bit level of a low-level question. SG&A was really low in the quarter, really good, really good cost control. And obviously, the incentive comp was part of that. But even with the incentive comp up like $100 million, again it seems have been the first 2 quarters. You still at $630 million, $640 million or something like very low levels. Is that -- what else was abnormal in SG&A? And what is the sort of indication of sustainable run rate from the quarter?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean the incentive comp was definitely an abnormal, if you will, in the quarter -- a good guy. Outside of that, I'm not aware of anything in the quarter that was of any materiality, unusual or weird. There's always some discretion in some of the ex
componenttext: Yes. I mean the incentive comp was definitely an abnormal, if you will, in the quarter -- a good guy. Outside of that, I'm not aware of anything in the quarter that was of any materiality, unusual or weird. There's always some discretion in some of the expense that you have, and there's always some timing issues. I'm quite confident that the SG&A costs might be a bit higher in the fourth quarter because of timing, but there's nothing that I'm aware of that is anything that's significantly, outside of incentive compensation, negative. Or positive. Yes.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Would you hazard a guess on the total? I mean, I understand the work that you're doing on product design but the total were all material benefit for 2016 [ph] at this point?
componenttext: Would you hazard a guess on the total? I mean, I understand the work that you're doing on product design but the total were all material benefit for 2016 [ph] at this point?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2016? Honestly, I don't remember the total number, but probably a good couple of hundred million dollars maybe, maybe a little bit more than that even.
componenttext: 2016? Honestly, I don't remember the total number, but probably a good couple of hundred million dollars maybe, maybe a little bit more than that even.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Joe O'Dea.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Joe O'Dea.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Vertical Research. First question, just on pricing and what's embedded in early expectations for '17. I think when we compare to the pricing announcement from late September, which had a pretty wide range, but flat to up 4%. And then based on experie
componenttext: It's Vertical Research. First question, just on pricing and what's embedded in early expectations for '17. I think when we compare to the pricing announcement from late September, which had a pretty wide range, but flat to up 4%. And then based on experience this quarter, just how you're thinking about kind of pricing from an overall perspective on -- in '17?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I -- that's a good question, Joe. And when asked for kinds of puts and takes for next year, I was silent on price realization. So on the positive side, we did put list prices up 4 machines in the range of some non -- some as much as 4. We don't provi
componenttext: Yes. I -- that's a good question, Joe. And when asked for kinds of puts and takes for next year, I was silent on price realization. So on the positive side, we did put list prices up 4 machines in the range of some non -- some as much as 4. We don't provide any kind of a weighting on that. So it's a little tough for you to know kind of what an overall average is for that. And then even that, that's just machines. So that wouldn't have aftermarket, and it's not energy & transportation either. So I think -- but I think the fact that we had a 0 to plus 4% range, you look at -- think of that as a bias for a little better price. The flip side of that is price realization this year, we did not take list prices down, but we have negative price realizations. So the market will be what the market will be, regardless of what we put out in list price changes. I think, at this point, I didn't talk about it as a headwind or a tailwind, and I think that probably describes it at this point anyway how we're thinking about it.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then specifically on construction inventory and the dealer channel, could you give any context around, historically, how many months of inventory the dealers have wanted to carry there and what they're carrying now and maybe where you see that
componenttext: Got it. And then specifically on construction inventory and the dealer channel, could you give any context around, historically, how many months of inventory the dealers have wanted to carry there and what they're carrying now and maybe where you see that going with the point of the question really being, how big an impact lean manufacturing has been for you? What kind of a comfort level gives your dealers? And so there's destock related to end market and there's also destock on efficiency and just how much more of that we could see?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I wish our intel on that, but -- I wish we were able to break down all the reasons and causes for everything that goes on within dealer inventory. There's usually a reasonable band in terms of months of supply. And you kind of have to look at it
componenttext: Yes. And I wish our intel on that, but -- I wish we were able to break down all the reasons and causes for everything that goes on within dealer inventory. There's usually a reasonable band in terms of months of supply. And you kind of have to look at it in a band. It's not a static kind of expectation. It depends a lot on -- is the bias up or is the bias down in future sales because that will color a lot what dealers hold. How were to your point, how we're shipping? Are we meeting shipping commitments? Are they relatively quick? Can they get what they want when they need it? And so that kind of puts downward bias on what they want to hold as well. The flip side of that is if in allocation. They won't order as much as they can get and they want to hold as much as they can keep. So there's not a hard and fast rule. But somewhere in the sort of maybe 3 months on the low end, 3.5, there's probably a reasonable band. And for the most part, we're in that band. And you have to even take that with a bit of a grain of salt because it depends upon kind of what the product mix is of what's being sold. So if it were all small machines that we sell, that we can provide delivery on in 8 weeks, it provides a bit different dealer dynamic benefits big machines that takes 6 months. But I guess the gist of my answer would be, I don't think there's any massive excess of dealer inventory. I think we'd all like to get dealer inventory down. It's just more efficient for us and dealers if we can deliver quickly what they want, what they need. And then in the ultimate world, wouldn't it be great if they didn't have to have any inventory, that we could just ship them everything in 1 day? Unfortunately, that's not the case. You're always striving to do better.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is coming from Mili Pothiwala.
componenttext: And the next question is coming from Mili Pothiwala.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Morgan Stanley. My question is on the comments you made on North American construction, particularly some of the weakness you mentioned you saw over the past quarter, call it, [indiscernible] a little more concerned on the outlook in 4Q and into next
componenttext: It's Morgan Stanley. My question is on the comments you made on North American construction, particularly some of the weakness you mentioned you saw over the past quarter, call it, [indiscernible] a little more concerned on the outlook in 4Q and into next year. Can you just elaborate on kind of where you're seeing that and what caused you to get a little bit more concerned?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you think about our business in construction, the heavy construction and rental are pretty decent-sized businesses for us. If you look at construction in North America, housing seems to be motoring on and has been okay. The problem we find ours
componenttext: Yes. So if you think about our business in construction, the heavy construction and rental are pretty decent-sized businesses for us. If you look at construction in North America, housing seems to be motoring on and has been okay. The problem we find ourselves in, I think, is the larger projects, the infrastructure spending is maybe not quite as robust as housing would be right now. And that's a bigger sweet spot for us. We have this other dynamic going on, and I'll try to describe it like this. We have too much used equipment in the marketplace right now, and used equipment prices are fairly depressed. And so what that causes in rental, particularly with our rental channel through CAT dealers, is it does not provide much of an incentive for dealers to sell off their used equipment and refresh fleets. So we're seeing the rent -- our sales into the rental channel as pretty challenged right now. And I talked about construction equipment in Resource Industries, in particular articulated trucks. We had quite a bit more rental loading earlier in the year than we've seen here in the back half of the year. So I think, hopefully, sentiment will improve. We'll get the election out of the way. We'll have a new government that's interested in infrastructure spending. And somewhere 6 months to a year down the road, maybe that will turn into something better. But right now, I think we're on the fence and concerned about overall construction in North America.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just another quick follow-up. I think, in the past, you've talked about, for 4Q, within Resource Industries kind of a breakeven outcome as being a possibility. Is that still how we should think about 4Q today?
componenttext: Got it. And then just another quick follow-up. I think, in the past, you've talked about, for 4Q, within Resource Industries kind of a breakeven outcome as being a possibility. Is that still how we should think about 4Q today?
